name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the protection of forest and environmental defenders in the EU (2019/2939 (RSP)). I would like to remind you once again that it is possible to make a request to be given the say in the 'catch-the-eye' procedure and the 'blue card question' procedure using both the 'normal procedure' and the electronic system. The relevant instructions are available at the entrance of the Hemicycle.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Commission is strongly committed to protecting and restoring existing forests, both within the European Union and worldwide. To this end, a comprehensive legislative framework exists at EU level. In particular, many forests are protected under the Birds and Habitats Directives. These Directives require that some forest habitats be maintained at or restored to favourable conservation status.  Currently 23% of the European Union’s forest area is part of the Natura 2000 network of protected sites. In addition, species protection rules under both the Birds and Habitats Directives apply within the whole EU territory.  Environmental defenders represent natural and indispensable allies in the promotion of environmental rights. Another tool is the Directive on Environmental Crime in the European Union. The Commission is currently evaluating how the Directive has contributed to the fight against environmental crime. The Commission is currently carrying out a wide public consultation, open until January 2020, and will assess the need to review this legislation or improve its implementation.  Finally, the Timber Regulation aims to prevent trade in illegally harvested timber and timber products.  Environmental crime is also considered a threat to European security and to the well-being of citizens. It has therefore been included in the EU policy cycle against serious and organised crime covering the period from 2018 to 2021. The European Union policy cycle’s primary objective is to increase cooperation amongst law enforcement services and EU agencies to disrupt organised crime groups through operational actions.  It is important to recall that Member States are responsible for implementing the relevant rules, as well as for taking appropriate enforcement measures, including sanctions and penalties. The Commission monitors the implementation of these rules and takes action when needed. The European Union is also providing financial means for the protection, restoration and sustainable management of forests in line with the EU forest strategy.  The European Union’s rural development funds under the common agricultural policy are the main source of funding for forests, amounting to EUR 8.2 billion of public expenditure in the current multiannual financial framework (MFF) period 2014-2020.  Last but not least, the recent Communication on stepping up EU action to protect and restore the world’s forests shows that the European Union is increasing its efforts to step up global action against biodiversity loss. This is currently being discussed in the Council and Parliament. In this context, I have to highlight again the important role of the Timber Regulation, which applies to both timber logged in third countries and imported into the European Union and to domestic timber logged in the European Union.  The Commission has been alerted to reported cases of continued illegal logging in some Member States, including in primary forests, and is carefully assessing the situation. On the specific case of Romania, the Commission is working with the authorities to assess the situation. It is also in the process of analysing Copernicus satellite imagery of logging activities in Natura 2000 protected areas.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Around 42% of the European Union's land area is covered by forests and more than three million Europeans are employed in the forestry sector. Their importance is immeasurable for all that life means on Earth, but also for depopulated areas where it creates real opportunities for employment. Green gold, however, is not inexhaustible. Today the world is called upon to fight against what does not know national or continental borders, namely the fight against the profound climate change that affects our daily lives. Sustainable forest management is extremely important in this respect, given the increased secretion of carbon dioxide. At all political levels, all that is necessary must be done to prevent the deterioration of the state of the forests and to restore their good condition where necessary. The European Commission and the Member States must once again support the measures necessary for the reforestation of degraded and agriculturalland.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Every year, women and men who fight for the protection of the environment are increasingly victims of violence and intimidation. In 2018, more than 160 people have died as a result of their fight for the environment around the world. When not killed, these activists are often subjected to abusive arrests, threats or violence for daring to oppose the interests of governments and businesses that appropriate their land or forests. Unfortunately, this violence is on the rise, and while Europe is not the continent most affected by this violence, it is not spared. In recent months, two people have been killed while fighting illegal logging in Romania, while in the UK, three people have been sentenced to long prison terms for their actions against shale gas development. Among human rights activists, environmental activists often face serious dangers because of the financial interests that their actions call into question. It is imperative that binding laws are required so that today these companies are held accountable for acts against activists. These companies - European companies that import raw materials and products from third countries - must now ensure that their partners and the entire supply chain respect human and environmental rights. The wood regulation is good regulation, but we need to go further in terms of corporate responsibility. Environmental activists must be able to look to Europe to protect them and ensure access to justice when they are victims of such violence. The justice system should not be a means of sinting activists, but of defending them against those who attack their rights and cause environmental damage. The criminalization of these activists only trivializes and makes legitimate the violence they suffer, which then promotes the continuation of the same violence. Such measures must better protect and defend environmental activists in Europe but also in the rest of the world.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr. President, forests are our life. They account for 30% of the Earth's surface area, but maintain 80% of biodiversity. Thanks to them we breathe. Thanks to them we live. We therefore very much welcome the Commission's concern for the protection of European forests and the world. The truth is that as the conditions of our forests worsen, the conditions of the people who defend them, of environmental defenders, are also deteriorating in the world. Some data have been given, and indeed, according to some reports, such as the Front Line Defenders report, in 2018 two hundred and forty-seven leaders and environmental leaders have been shot, persecuted or have disappeared precisely for defending their environmental environment, for defending the right of all. Because it must be said that the destruction of biodiversity does not concern environmental laws exclusively but should be regarded as a violation of international human rights. In this sense, the European Union must take steps to defend the people who defend our environment. We must improve our environmental legislation and fight environmental crimes. Indeed, as has also been cited, forty environmental organizations around the world are protesting and demanding justice in connection with the murder last month of two forest guards in Romania who had denounced the illegal logging of the forests in their region. According to the Commission's own data, 43% of the timber obtained in these Romanian forests in 2015 came from unidentified sources. Certification, labelling that certifies a deforestation-free value chain, both from European and international forests, is absolutely necessary in the European Union. I believe that the Commission should take on this task.

name: Marie TOUSSAINT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, their name was Reddu Gorcioaia and Liviu Pop, they were forest rangers and were murdered this autumn because they were only doing their duty, which is to protect the forest. In all, not two but six forest rangers have been killed by the timber mafia in recent years in Romania. They protected nature, but no one protected them. Protectors and protectors of the environment are indeed targets, and we know that. Every year, nearly 200 conservationists are killed around the world. Every week, three people are killed because they defend their natural property, their land or simply their rights to the mining, forestry or agri-food industries. Every day, women and men who defend nature are attacked, silenced, defamed, arrested or threatened with death. The NGO Global Witness points out that this harassment is linked to eco-criminal mafias, but it is also the result of the actions of states that put in place policies aimed at criminalizing and intimidating environmentalists. Cynicism kills, greed kills and indifference kills. This is most often happening outside our borders, as in Brazil's Bolsonaro, our trading partner, where, on Tuesday, the NGO Sa'dee e Alegria and four environmentalists were searched by soldiers and falsely accused of deliberately setting fire to Alter do Cho in order to receive international donations. The same is true in the European Union with the Romanian forest rangers, or Rémi Fraisse, killed by a grenade from the French police, or the activists opposed to hydraulic fracturing who have received prison sentences in the United Kingdom. The silence of the Union is worth complicity; it is time to put an end to it and it is time for the Union to finally condemn crimes against nature and those who protect it. It is time for the Union to finally and forcefully honour the lives and commitments of those who allow us to live on a livable land today.

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to go beyond the European framework. Environmental advocates are targets around the world. According to NGOs, at least 164 environmentalists were killed last year. They fought against mining, forestry or agribusiness projects, but others were silenced by intimidation and violence. With this sad diagnosis, how can we help them? It is always possible to put pressure on states and multinationals that encourage such violence for ever greater profit, but above all we will help these heroic defenders of the environment if we too change our consumption habits. Logging, poaching, mass and intensive agriculture exist and develop because there is a demand in Europe's supermarkets: wood for our furniture, soy for beef and palm oil for shampoos. Indeed, EU consumption accounts for about 10% of the world's share of deforestation, which is mainly due to the consumption of these products. Our role as politicians is to alert and inform the citizens of our respective countries, to offer them to consume in an eco-responsible way and to encourage them to do so. There is an urgent need to stop all international treaties that promote the plundering of land resources.

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I do not think that there should be any specific legislation for environmental activists in the sense that all countries in the European Union have laws that protect all citizens.  I don't know who we have to protect so-called defenders from. Those who cry hysterically for protection do not protect nature. In Bulgaria, they are called "poisonous green". These are NGOs that not only sabotage billion-dollar projects of the European Union, not only are they engaged in eco-tourism, but they are also abusing EU funds. This was revealed in many journalistic investigations. Because of them, the word "ecology" has become a dirty word. I am puzzled that the Green parties at all support such strange organisations that only harm their cause. Thanks to these non-governmental organizations at the last elections in Bulgaria, the Greens took exactly 0 percent. The Greens' colleagues need to clear their ranks of these bogus nature ers, as these compromised NGOs do not need protection, but from a court.

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, in a few hours in this Chamber we will be called to declare the European Union a climate emergency. I hope we do, because that's what's happening on our planet, and we're doing it not to protect the planet or to destroy the planet, we can't do either. We are doing this because this emergency is about people's health. We are doing this to protect people and to recognise that the highest human right is the right to breath and the environment that has allowed us to evolve into the beings we are today.  In recent years, more than five people a year have been killed, murdered, protecting natural resources. This battle will be continued by climate fighters, mainly indigenous peoples, who protect their land and protect ourselves. Forests protect them because they protect us from overexe exposure to carbon dioxide. So we have to stand by them. In Romania, in our country, in London and everywhere we will see more climate fighters, as more and more resources are being used for more and more people. We must also set up an emergency helpline, provide legal support and also create a mechanism for responding immediately to environmental crimes.

name: Alexander BERNHUBER
text: Mr President, representative of the European Commission, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work he has done on this Time and again, self-proclaimed environmentalists invade stables during night and fog actions, disturbing animals and taking pictures in the barn. Until now, it has been impossible for affected farmers in Austria to prosecute unauthorised intrusion into property. In our National Council in Austria, a law to this effect was unfortunately rejected this year, and no approval was given by the FPÖ and other parties. Our farmers need effective opportunities throughout Europe to combat illegal incursions into their property. It cannot be right for someone to simply invade foreign property, leave behind uncertainty and devastation, and perhaps then publish pictures or videos that were manipulated and misinform people about it. It's just not okay! It is not environmentalists who need more protection from the EU, but our farmers need more protection and action from the EU against radical environmentalists.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! Let us start with the good news: in the vast majority of countries in Europe, we are beginning to see that more forest is coming again. We in the European Union have succeeded in reversing the trend. Forests in Europe have grown with an area the size of Greece since 1990. Of course, we are not in the finish line yet, but positive progress has been made. It is important that our Member States turn up their ambitions in this area, for example my own Member State, Denmark, has chosen to want to sixfold the area of untouched forest. I hope that other countries will follow along.  But we cannot do without action at European level. That is why it is quite important that we have a new European Environmental Action Programme or equivalent, which looks at pristine forest and our biodiversity and the climate. In that programme, I also think it is important that we make an effort to protect the people who help protect our nature. How it should look, I do not necessarily need to describe in detail here. I think it is important that we also intervene from the European side and safeguard the people who help protect our forests. In addition, we need to get the existing rules much better enforced. This also means punishing those who do not comply with the rules we have in Europe. We can scale up! We must do much more to protect our forests and to protect those who protect our forests!

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Forests are absolutely very important for maintaining the cleanliness of the air, and I do not have to convince anyone here. I would like to draw attention to the fact that we should create the best possible conditions for Member States to manage forests well. Poland is such a good example of good forest management, which is at the forefront when it comes to forest area in the European Union. Today it is more than nine million hectares. We have a forestry level of almost thirty percent. The vast majority are state forests and Polish state forests are an example of how forest resources can be managed prudently and wisely. More than five hundred million new trees are planted in Poland every year. On this occasion, I would like to draw attention to the fact that was raised here in the High House a few years ago, namely the subject of the Białowieża Forest. When a printer bark beetle appeared in the forest cover, environmentalists protested against the felling of sick trees. Today the wilderness dies. Twenty-five percent of the wilderness is already dead. This is the result of the work of unpredictable environmentalists... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: – Mr President, our precious nature does not have a voice, and the brave people who stand up to defend it risk their lives by doing so. I want to tell you the story of a Romanian activist, Gabriel Paun from Agent Green. He is in the European Parliament today. He risked his life trying to prevent trees becoming cheap furniture, trees harvested from the Domogled National Park in the Retezat Mountains. He has been attacked many, many times. In 2015, the ‘lumber mafia’ broke his head, his ribs, and his hand with the intention to kill him. While it was all recorded, it took prosecutors four years to send the attackers to court. Last year, they cut down big trees in aiming to crush him and his car, to block him from filming their illegal logging. The authorities protect the illegal loggers by manipulating the official figures of the volume of wood that is taken each year from Romania’s forest. This is unacceptable. What will the Commission do to protect our forests and to protect the people who defend them?

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I agree that the defence of the environment is a fundamental human rights battleground. I would like to strongly condemn the murder of two workers or forest defenders in Romania. At the same time, I would like to stress that, in most cases, defenders are actually acting in the public interest because they are trying to protect the environment, sustainable development and, in general, human rights. However, there must also be no abuse of rights, where manipulation takes place, abuse of the position of defenders, so it is not possible to provide them with any above-standard protection there. In economically less developed countries, indigenous and local communities primarily protect their natural resources. While this topic is only about the state of forests and protectors in the European Union, let us not forget that there are communities in the world that naturally protect their natural resources. Indeed, there has been a break in the trend in forestry, the state of the forest is improving in Europe, but we must not fall asleep on our laurels. I would like to underline that we must continue to afforestation and protect the forest.

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – Mr President, for the last couple of years we have been witnessing increasing numbers of protests in defence of the natural environment in the EU. Environmental activists, like those in Białowieża Forest or Camp for Climate in Poland, engage in great service to humanity, and their demands are compelling. When the Polish part of the Białowieża Forest, registered at the UNESCO World Heritage, was the subject of massive cuts, environmental defenders were there to stop deforestation and alert public opinion. The European Community must not watch silently as environmental defenders are harassed, arrested and face charges for what they do. I call for increasing efforts to protect and fulfil environmental defenders rights within the EU. The EU needs a clear line on this issue. Those who protect the environment are heroes, not criminals.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr More and more countries are prohibiting the involvement of organisations defending democracy, the environment and even human rights. Those who fight for our environment and nature are subjected to threats, harassment and even murder. On average, there are three murders per week anywhere in the world. I have just heard the news of the murdered forest rangers here in Europe who have tried to protect the oldest primeval forests from destruction and theft. It should be self-evident for all Member States and businesses in Europe to protect nature. It must be self-evident to always protect the people who already do.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, the restoration and protection of the European forest is obviously a major political issue. Having said that, I hear this debate and I think that we should stop being hypocrites already. We are protecting ourselves and the European forest, but we are exporting deforestation by signing trade treaties that encourage the destruction of forests and, in particular, primary forests. I refer you to our next trade agreement with Vietnam and our trade agreement with Mercosur, which is being negotiated and is an incentive for deforestation. This hypocrisy must therefore be put to an end. There is an ecological issue, as everyone has said, but there is also a social issue, which we have rightly talked about by referring to environmentalists who are now criminalized, sometimes hunted down. I also have a thought for the workers of the forest, forestry, who live in very degraded social conditions, with a proven social dumping, and suffer from downsizing. I am also thinking of privatization, for example that of the National Forestry Office in France. These forestry and wood workers must be protected. Finally, I think we need better coordination of European policies. We have a lot of scattered texts when we need an ambitious and harmonious "forests" legislative package that integrates all our thinking on agricultural policy, organic development and trade policy. That is the real work of our legislature.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: – Mr President, I have grown up surrounded by old oaks and chestnut trees. In my land, as in the rest of Europe, forests are the lives and lungs of our ecosystems. For centuries they have been heat, shelter and food. All those who protect our trees are worthy of defence by this Parliament, whether it is the Romanian guards — to whom we send our solidarity and condemn what they are suffering – or NGOs. I know well how you can fight for a forest from civil society and institutions.  I want to take the opportunity to make a plea for all the indigenous and primitive forests of Europe, some threatened and assaulted by greed. On the Atlantic facade of the Iberian Peninsula we are losing the traditional forests. As in other parts of Europe, our old forest cover – varied and full of life – is being replaced by forest monocultures that represent only particular interests, impoverish the soil and promote the action of arsonists.  We must also know that planting forests is not the same as creating a forest. For this reason we must support and reinforce the work of those who care because they are also taking care of us and those who are to come, remembering that a primitive forest is a persevering and stubborn fighter against climate change.  (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Daniel BUDA
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mr President, I would like to ask the distinguished colleague whether he agrees with what has happened in Romania, and I say that it is a good thing that from today the rangers in Romania have the right to bear lethal weapons, firearms, precisely in order to defend themselves better and if he believes that this could be extended to other rangers in the European Union.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: "blue card" response. – I think the situation in Romania is very unique. I certainly do not share that this extension is logical for all the countries of the European Union. Certainly not for mine.  Now we do, we have to provide them, if not with those tools, with weapons but legal, that the laws protect them more than today.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I have subscribed to a few comments. Firstly, I want to say that the European Union must also help Member States to restore forests in the next programming period. It is true that the area of forests in Europe has increased, but it is also true that their quality has deteriorated in many parts, as a result of climate change, fluctuations, especially drought, and pests. I think, therefore, that once again the Regional Development Fund will have to support the efforts of foresters in afforestation. On this occasion, I would like to thank the hundreds of volunteers in the Czech Republic who have participated in the restoration of the forest this year. Thousands of hectares, I think it's a demonstration that people don't care what condition the lungs of this planet are in. And we, the Members of the European Parliament, do not care how the Brazilian President has approached extinguishing fires in the Amazon. I ask the Commission to continue the initiative of Council President Tusk, who has offered to help and has asked for the firefighting to be intense, otherwise we will not sign an agreement with Mercosur. If Brazil does not put out its fire in the Amazon, I will not agree to a deal with Mercosur.

name: Vlad-Marius BOTOŞ
text: – Mr President, colleagues, thank you for almost all of you highlighting Romania in your speeches, thank you very much. The forests of Romania, as you said each of you, cry every day. I'm crying because the axes are talking. Every hour hectares of forest disappear and yes, this is happening in Europe, where the priorities are protecting the environment and reducing emissions. I would like a more active involvement of the European Union in countries where the forest is not respected, and I am glad, Commissioner, that you highlighted Romania in today's speech and thank you for your visit to Bucharest this year. The European Union's position on national policies in which the forest is not respected will need to be more efficient, clearer. Carelessness can lead to natural disasters, loss of rare ecosystems and loss of life. For decades, maybe even hundreds of years, we'll have to reforest the areas that have disappeared. Our generation has a responsibility to keep them healthy for the next generations and I thank you again for highlighting Romania in your speeches, but let us give the forests due importance throughout this green platform that we are talking about.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Mr President, we have criticised deforestation in countries outside the European Union several times. Unfortunately, we must now address this problematic issue at our level as well. And here, too, in the European Union, life is at stake. In Romania, two foresters have recently died due to the so-called mining mafia. I find it completely unacceptable that such events should take place anywhere in the world, and it is absolutely shocking that this is happening here, in the European Union. It is also madness that every day, nine hectares of forest disappear in Romania and we sit and watch it. I take it that the Paris climate agreement is simply a piece of paper for us to discuss, but it means virtually nothing, and if we can want to enforce it, we do not? Because that's exactly what it looks like. We're lecturing everyone around us, and we're not able to get our house in order. Commissioner, I call on you to take a very active action against what is happening in Romania and to act very actively so that not only there are no murders, but above all, so as not to lose such a precious forest.  My condolences to the families of those who lost loved ones.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, I invite all Europarlamentary MEMBERS, especially the 20 of us here who are currently in the hall to protect forests on the European continent.  A colleague just mentioned the wood mob. The wood mafia also exists in the Republic of Croatia. I will explain this in several numbers: in the three decades since the beginning of Croatia, we have forested 500 km squared forests through eight different adhesion methods. It's questionable what was received from it all, but it's a statistic. In just one decade, we've cut down 1,000 square miles illegally, so with what we regularly cut, planningly, legally, we cut this much illegally and at a minimum. Those are conservative estimates. Organized crime took the management of Croatian forests, cut down without any order and plan, does not cut down the maquis, cuts down the best, most beautiful trees that then go to other countries of the European Union for no money. Although it cuts more than ever, it has never been harder to reach Croatian processors to wood.  Forests and large areas around Croatia are increasingly reminiscent of the Lunar Surface, and the Croatian state, as it is not able to deal with any mafia, unfortunately, is not able to deal alone with this mafia, so I invite you all to protect the public good of all of us and to preserve forests on the European continent.

name: Mauri PEKKARINEN
text: – Mr President, this is an important debate. But we must add to this, and we must remind you here that there are also many countries within the European Union where the protection of forests, the protection of biodiversity and the industrial use of forests go hand in hand in a sustainable way. Finland is an example of such countries. We have protected forests with varying degrees of conservation standards totalling 44 000 square kilometres. That's a little more than the entire danish area. At the same time, we use forests in an industrially sustainable way. The forests are used to produce bio-based, renewable, sustainable products. These two things can go hand in hand. Nevertheless, I say that there is still much to be done in Europe and throughout the world to promote the protection of forests, but also the sustainable exploitation of forests – to carry these two things hand in hand.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, the recent murder of two Romanian forest rangers highlights the urgent need to protect Europe’s environmental defenders and to save Europe’s last old—growth forests.  More than 160 environmental defenders were murdered in 2018, and thousands more were criminalised and hounded in countries such as the Philippines, India, Brazil and Colombia.  We do need effective EU legislation that establishes a mandatory human rights and environmental due—diligence framework for companies and financial institutions that are EU—based or that provide goods or services in the EU so as to make companies accountable for the impact of their activities. We are well aware of the much abuse of forests in Brazil at the moment, with the deforestation that’s taking place. The EU is complicit by the trade deals we’re doing with them. Mercosur will increase deforestation and we should not go down that path. Not only will it destroy small farms in Europe but it is going to destroy more forests. We should not sign that deal.

name: Neven Mimica
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, today’s discussion was very important. We all agree that we have to protect and restore the world’s forests, as well as to protect environmental defenders who stand up so courageously to protect nature. Indeed, environmental defenders are indispensable allies in the promotion of environmental rights. I would like to pay tribute to the recently murdered rangers Liviu Pop and Răducu Gorcioaia, and express my heartfelt condolences to their families. While assessing the need for additional legislative and regulatory measures, we should already implement effectively the existing ones. The central responsibility lies with the national authorities. We need to work with Member States to ensure implementation and enforcement of European Union and national law on the ground. In that context, the Commission will continue cooperating with the national authorities, including in Romania, to ensure the complete implementation and enforcement of EU legislation.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – The new UN Environment Programme report warns that unless global greenhouse gas emissions fall by 7.6% each year between 2020 and 2030, the world will miss the opportunity to get on track towards the 1.5 C temperature goal of the Paris Agreement. thus, it is high time we realise how important forests are. As 43% of EU land is covered by forests, their role go well beyond carbon neutrality. A sustainable and active forest management contributes also to climate change mitigation and adaptation, improves energy security, creates jobs and promotes economic growth. Therefore, it is essential to ensure coordination among various forest-related EU policies. The main tool to do that is the European Green New Deal, as it provides a framework for a well-coordinated action at EU level. Therefore, I hope forests will play an important role in this document, which is to be presented soon. I cannot forget what is happening with forests back in my country, Romania - almost 600 forest rangers have been killed or seriously injured combatting illegal logging, while 3 hectares of forests are illegally cut every hour. I put all my hope and I will fight to protect EU forests.

name: Christine SCHNEIDER
text: Writing. – Forest and environmental activists are an indispensable part of strengthening environmental rights. Here too, however, the regulatory framework applies, and the end does not justify every means. I would like to see better cooperation with the competent authorities so that we can protect our forests and our environment well.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on five motions for resolutions on the situation of freedoms in Algeria (2019/2927 (RSP)).

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since I have been a Member of Parliament, we have voted on resolutions on a wide range of issues, on countries as far away as Indonesia, but we have not had a word about the great revolution taking place just across the Mediterranean in Algeria. We have not had a word of support for the millions of Algerians who have been marching through the streets of Algiers and other Algerian cities for nine months for democracy, justice and dignity. We have not had a word about the arrests, the pressures and the violence that are falling on them, nor have we had a word about the now-proven cases of torture. This complicit silence, skilfully maintained by powerful lobbies, can no longer last. The solidarity resolution that we are going to vote on today is not interference, it is the end of a huge injustice. It is time, ladies and gentlemen, to show that we stand with the Algerian people. So, as they say in my house: one, two, three, viva Algeria!

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: Author. Mr President, High Representative, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and for the work she has In the last two months, the Algerian government has forcibly closed at least eight Protestant churches, Christian and Jewish cemeteries have been destroyed, and Algeria's small Christian communities are being persecuted by the state. Algeria's blasphemy laws make it difficult for Christians to practice their faith without prosecution. Indeed, Algerian authorities criminalize peaceful speeches, arrest people who do not fast during Ramadan, and use state intimidation to restrict minority religions. The following figures make the extent of the persecution of Christians particularly clear: a century ago, Christians made up 20% of the population in the Middle East and North Africa, today it is only 4%. Earlier this year, the French Parliament officially opened an investigation into the persecution of Christians in Algeria. That is what we should be doing. And we must be seriously concerned about the persecution of minorities around the world who preserve their Judeo-Christian heritage. We must demand that Algerian Parliamentary Regulation 0603 be repealed immediately and that Christians be able to exercise their faith without fear of intimidation, violence and discrimination.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Author. Mr President, the government in Algeria has unfortunately shown its true face over the last two years: a face against freedom of religion. In recent years, the Algerian government has closed 15 Protestant churches, seven of them in the past three months. In fact, people were injured during a church closure in Tizi Ouzou on 16 October. The Ahmadi community in Algeria has also been heavily targeted. In the period June 2016 to March 2018, no less than 315 Ahmadis were persecuted because of their religious beliefs. It is also a clear and clear signal from the 2018 report on human rights by the External Action Service. It clearly states: 'In Algeria, the scope for active citizenship and the right to association and assembly is limited'.  Freedom of religion is a fundamental human right. Part of that right is the right to be able to come together in churches and other places of worship. What we are seeing now in Algeria, but unfortunately also in several countries in the Middle East, is that these powers are being thwarted. That right is being violated. I expect the High Representative to take a strong stand against this, because it is unacceptable what is happening now; church closures must be undone. I assume that the special envoy for religion and freedom of faith is also closely involved in this process, because what is happening in Algeria is now in breach of all rights.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: Author. Mr President, let us imagine, let us hope, let us dream for a moment! Let us imagine that this immense movement that has been raising Algeria for so many months, young, determined and aspiring to dignity, the rule of law and equity, let us imagine that this movement prevails. It would not only be the happiness and pride of Algeria, it would be the mobilization of all these energies in favour of the resumption of inter-Maghrebin dialogue, economic and cultural cooperation with Europe, and aid from both sides of the Mediterranean to sub-Saharan Africa. It would be the realization of our common aspirations for all of us, North Africans and Europeans. That is why we must adopt this resolution, against an intolerable and absurd repression that risks breaking this beautiful Algerian dream. Let us say to Algeria in struggle, hope, support and affection of Europe.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: co-author of the motion for a resolution. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Earlier this autumn, the proposal to debate church closures was voted down by, among others, Swedish parliamentarians from the Green Party, the Center Party and the Liberals. As a co-author, I am therefore very pleased that today we can debate this important issue. I note, however, that the concept of religious freedom was removed from the title of this resolution. This is not the first time that watering takes place in this house from the centre/left when it comes to persecuted Christians. It reminds me of when the Socialist Group demanded that the resolution on the mass murder of islamic state should not include genocide in the title. Stop ignoring the persecution of Christians. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratul The EU will have donated well over SEK 1 billion to Algeria in the period 2018-2020. At the same time, the Algerian authorities have intensified the campaign against Christians. Fifteen churches have been closed since 2018. Christian communities and congregations cannot register and therefore do not receive building permits for the construction of churches. Church closures and other violations are contrary to the UN Convention on Human Rights and algeria's constitution. We must put pressure on Algeria to change its policy immediately. We can bring about change.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which A week ago today, I had the opportunity to speak in my home country of Vienna at the peace symposium of Ahmadiyya Muslims in Austria on the topic of "world peace". Other religious communities were also represented there. Now, as we debate here, the Happy Hour Of Free Speech is taking place here in the House, where we are talking to each other on a non-partisan basis: with Damian Boeselager of the Greens, with Irena Joveva of Renew Europe, with Francois-Xavier Bellamy of the European People's Party and with Eva Maydell of the European People's Party.  I say this because European values, which are universal values, are also being lived. Human dignity and individual freedom, freedom of conscience and belief are lived. Because these are universal values, we have a responsibility to say loudly when things happen, as in Algeria, where Ahmadiyya Muslims – the very denomination I was allowed to speak at the previous week – are put under arrest in Algeria for their faith. When 15 churches are closed, when websites that shape freedom of expression are closed, when women's organisations are closed, we speak out loud. The election will take place in Algeria on 12 December. Algerian citizens should know how to decide when it comes to freedom.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the group, Mr President, for more than nine months, Algerian citizens have been the admiration of the world for their democratic demands expressed peacefully but above all determinedly. We know Algeria is committed to respecting fundamental human rights by being a signatory to several international treaties, including the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to name but a few. Respect for freedom of expression and demonstration are therefore guaranteed by the Algerian Constitution. However, dozens of prominent figures are currently in detention for simply expressing an option, on the pretext that they would undermine national unity. Media outlets have been put under pressure and have had to cease their activities, as well as NGOs. With our resolution, the European Parliament urges the Algerian authorities to release all political prisoners and prisoners of conscience. The human rights and fundamental freedoms that Algeria is committed to uphold must be guaranteed, especially freedoms of expression and demonstration. Europe is a friend of Algeria but above all a friend of all Algerians. It is our duty to recall the common partnership priorities adopted in March 2017, in which both sides reaffirmed their commitment to the universal values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights.

name: Phil BENNION
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, the democratic protests in Algeria seemed to have achieved their objective when President Bouteflika reversed his decision to stand for a fifth consecutive term in April of this year. However, the leaders of the various protest movements have been detained in recent months by what is increasingly looking like a military regime. It would be a tragedy if Algeria misses this opportunity to alter course and join its neighbours Morocco and Tunisia in becoming a country more open to the outside world.  I call for the release of all of these prisoners and I echo my colleagues’ concern about religious freedoms and the opening up of religious freedom, and when these elections come along they need to be free and fair. Then I would like to see Algeria open its borders with Morocco and Tunisia to form a Maghreb Union, as a strong and effective partner to the European Union, so that it can go forward with economic development that brings prosperity and peace to the Maghreb area.

name: Salima YENBOU
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Greens/FTA Group refused to support the inclusion of an emergency resolution on Algeria on the agenda of the plenary session for the following reasons: the choice of the political agenda, which takes place just before the elections on 12 December; the risk of politicizing human rights; the risk of degrading the legitimacy or credibility of the opposition and Algerians who have been protesting for nine months; the risk of fuelling the rhetoric of the regimes in power on alleged foreign interference; the conviction that Algeria deserves much more than a resolution which, although with strong and important messages of support for Algerians, has shortcomings and irrelevant references. Despite these reservations, we will vote in favour of this resolution. However, our support for the Algerian people will not end there, as we have done since March 2019. We remain mobilized alongside the Algerian people in their legitimate claim for their freedom and rights. We welcome the example of the Algerian people in their way of expressing their desire for change in an extremely peaceful way. In the end, we want the Algerian people to decide their own future. And as they say at home, in the language of Algerians: (...), let Algeria live!

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: There are requests for blue card questions, I would remind you that we are in the circle of speakers on behalf of the political groups, during which there are no blue card questions and that is why the possibility of making such a request by electronic procedure has not been activated. Therefore, when we complete this cycle you will be given this opportunity in accordance with the Rules of Procedure.

name: Gilbert COLLARD
text: on behalf of the ID group. - Mr President, what is happening in Algeria cannot leave anyone indifferent for two reasons. The first is principles; the second is reality. The principles, that is, that we must act to defend them wherever freedoms are violated. The reality is tears, suffocation, blood, distress and also the fact that between Algeria and France, there is a historical, economic, political and emotional connection. If people are bad there, they leave Algeria and arrive in difficult conditions in France, which can no longer - and not who no longer wants - to welcome. I believe that we must approve this resolution in the name of freedoms, our principles and, perhaps, what makes us exist.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, the messages that reach us from Algeria are of great concern to us. Not only am I talking about the way in which the protesters are being treated, but I am also talking emphatically about freedom of religion, which is being seriously violated: churches being closed down on the orders of the police and churchgoers being forcibly evicted from their places of worship. With this joint resolution, in particular paragraph 4, we as a Parliament are sending a strong signal to the Algerian authorities that what is happening to us is really unacceptable. Above all, let us use the partnership we have with Algeria in the context of Euromed to raise the issues of freedom of religion. I am counting on the High Representative, in her contacts with Algeria, to convey with a high priority our concerns about freedom of religion.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, yesterday was Red Wednesday. This day is recognised internationally, and is dedicated to Christians who are persecuted for their beliefs. According to the World Watch List, Algeria is placed 22 out of 50 countries that most persecute Christians. This year the Algerian Ministry of the Interior closed 15 Protestant churches and declared them illegal. Worshipers and pastors have been assaulted by police forces in raids targeted on churches during mass services. We demand for all churches to be rightfully re-opened. We demand for the Ministry of the Interior to approve the application of Christian organisations. I also encourage the EU to pressure Algerian officials to comply with the guarantee of freedom of religion established in the Algerian constitution. Thank you for the broad support from across the political parties, I’m very happy about it.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, the Algerian regime oppresses freedom; it has been oppressing freedoms since 22 February, the launch day of the Hirak, the popular peaceful protest movement born in the streets of Algiers that has now spread throughout the country. Protesters today have in the sights the presidential election of 12 December, which was fixed by the army and announces a little more the glaciation of power. The Algerian regime is violating the rights of students, journalists, trade unionists and workers who have been on the streets for ten months now, and those, in particular, of the 42 demonstrators sentenced to six months in prison for marching with the Amazigh banner. Because today, flying a Berber flag through the streets of Algiers leads to prison. Our resolution condemns all these authoritarian excesses of the regime; it speaks of our attachment to the thirst for independence of the Algerian people and the youth who suffer from ill-life. As they say there too (...), we ask for freedom for the Algerian people.

name: Marco DREOSTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, I regret to see that the title of this resolution has been removed from the term 'religious freedom', as if religion were taboo. Why can we not talk openly about religious persecution and, in particular, persecution of Christians? I would remind you that Algeria is the twenty-second most difficult country in the world to be a Christian. We remembered earlier that, in October alone, the Algerian Government closed three churches, including the largest in the country, arresting, among other things, the protesting faithful, and often the victims of persecution are Christians converted from Islam. For us, religious freedom is a fundamental and inalienable right of the human person. Unfortunately, feelings of hostility towards religion, particularly Christian religion, develop in certain circles. I humbly take up the words of Pope Benedict XVI, when he says that there is a risk of understanding secularism in terms of rejecting the social relevance of religion. For these reasons, ladies and gentlemen, it was extremely important not to conceal the words 'religious freedom', hiding, once again, behind politically correct terminology.

name: Jorge BUXADÉ VILLALBA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all concerned about the news coming from Algeria. We are concerned about the persecution of political leaders, the repression of demonstrations, the arbitrary detention of journalists, but we are particularly concerned about attacks on freedom of worship and religious freedom. Attacks on Christian minorities. However, we must be very careful on this issue, unless the European Union's characteristic 'goodness' leads us to make decisions that move the hornet and effects like in Libya or Syria that are much worse than we initially had. On the other hand, I would also like to point out that I do not believe that any of us in this Parliament have been voted by the voters to solve Algeria's problems, but to solve the problems of our nationals. And in this respect, I am also particularly concerned that Algeria is one of the countries that works least with the Member States in the return of migrants who enter Europe irregularly, especially in Spain where they enter Almeria, Murcia or the Balearic Islands. The European Union's ability to require third states to comply with our regulations and repatriation to avoid the so-called effect is an essential element in immigration policy.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Mr President, for 130 years, from 1830 to 1962, Algeria was a country where religious freedom reigned. For 130 years, Christians, Jews and Muslims could practice their respective religions in total serenity, apart from any extremist reading, starting with that of Islam. For nearly 60 years, the Algerian power that emerged from the FLN has continued to undermine the free religious practice of Jewish and Christian minorities, until they were almost disappearing from the country. Today, holding a Bible in your bag can cost up to five years in prison. These relentless attacks are also attacked against memory. Successive governments have deliberately allowed violent vandalism against Jewish and Christian cemeteries. It is because it has lost this pluralism that Algeria, for 30 years, has been sinking, tossed between a totalitarian regime and jihadist terrorism. Without repentance or false modesty, we must condemn and confront its responsibilities with an intolerant and worn-out power.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would also, of course, like to condemn the violence that has been taking place in Algeria over the last few months, when huge crowds of citizens are rebelling against the situation in the country. State power suppresses all human rights, I think algeria has somewhat escaped our perceptions, and we should unequivocally condemn these cases of human rights suppression – even torture and humiliation. At the same time, I would also like to unequivocally condemn the violence being committed against minorities, especially Christian ones. We have been sending considerable development aid to Algeria for several long decades. I think that, for this development aid, we have the right to expect a clear fulfilment of the conditions from the Algerian Government. I would like our development aid – I would also like to call on the High Representative who is here today and thank her for her support – to be conditional on the real fulfilment of these commitments by the Algerian Government.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Vice-President Mogherini, of course we have reason to discuss Algeria in a foreign policy debate. What can European diplomacy do to promote democracy and rights where there has been such a harsh and prolonged repression? Is it necessary to recall that Algeria was once a territory of application of European law, between 1957 and 1962? He gained independence, but not freedom. There has been a repressive military regime for too long, which has been being ousited lately with arbitrary detentions, pre-trial prisons and mass arrests of dissidents and opponents so that such due elections cannot take place since President Buteflika, after thirty years, finally resigned from re-election, to re-run for president. He was replaced by the President of the Senate, who called an election for July 4, then postponed to September 12 and finally to December 12, but which have not yet taken place. Attempts are being made to systematically suppress dissent. The European Union has the right to exercise all its diplomacy in order to try to restore normalcy, fundamental rights so that democracy and freedom are finally possible in Algeria.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: Mr President, my group is not a signatory to this resolution, but as far as I am concerned, I support both the spirit and the letter. Of course, we did not wait today to stand with the Algerian democrats who are fighting tirelessly against corruption, for fundamental freedoms and for social justice. Indeed, today, as we speak, there is repression, journalists are worried, protesters are unjustly imprisoned, the opposition is being undermined. Of course, we can't keep quiet. Like some colleagues, I also regret that this resolution is coming now rather than in February, when a powerful citizen movement was rising, which would have needed our support. While the electoral process is as questionable as it is contested, I know for a fact that the government will use our work to talk about interference and refer protesters to hypothetical foreign agents. But the truth is this political situation; it is not interference on our part but unwavering support that we give to the Algerian people, and in particular to a youth hungry for dignity, freedom and justice. She is the one we are thinking about today as we speak.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I, as my colleagues, also support this motion for a resolution. It is clear that we must stand up for the Algerian people, who express their political preferences, their desire for human rights, freedom and democracy. Let us do our utmost – and it will probably be the subject of important work by another high representative responsible for foreign policy – to contribute to the free and democratic presidential elections in Algeria. It will also be very important to draw attention to the rise of religious intolerance of the Algerian elite and government towards religious minorities. This is a really big problem, we clearly have to side with ethnic and religious minorities, not just Christians, and we must make it clear that, unfortunately, the development in Algeria recently has been rather negative and a departure from European values.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, ‘all of them must step down’ cry tens of thousands of Algerian protesters, voicing their demands that key officials from the Bouteflika era should resign before the country holds new elections. Twice—weekly protests have taken place since Bouteflika’s resignation, gaining momentum in recent weeks. Meanwhile the authorities are ramping up the arrest of peaceful protesters with quick-fire trials and 18—month jail terms. We call on the authorities to ensure fair and open trials for all protesters, and we deplore any action targeted at peaceful protesters. The army, now the main player in Algeria’s politics, has repeatedly vowed transparency ahead of the vote. Reporters Without Borders has warned that Algerian journalists are under growing pressure to portray the election in a favourable light. But four journalists with the pro—government daily Le Temps d’Algérie were suspended when one of them accused the management of censorship. The others were suspended when they walked out in solidarity. We call on the authorities to respect freedom of speech and democracy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, is comharsa linn í an Ailgéir agus is ceart go mbeadh caidreamh maith againn léi, mar a bhíonn againn de ghnáth. Ach ag an am céanna, caithfidh imní a bheith orainn faoi cad atá ag tarlú ann le déanaí, go háirithe a mhéid a bhaineann leis na heaglaisí.  Tá sé sin tábhachtach domsa agus do mo ghrúpa féin, mar is Críostaithe Daonlathacha sinne agus caithfimid seasamh do na Críostaithe agus na heaglaisí i gcoitinne timpeall an domhain. Agus níl aon chiall in aon chor leis an bhfíoras go bhfuil na heaglaisí á ndúnadh anois san Ailgéir agus géarchéim agus míchothromaíocht á mbronnadh orthu. Dá bhrí sin caithfimid brú a chur orthu é sin a chosc mar - cad a dhéanann na heaglaisí? Níl siad ann ach chun grá agus cothromaíocht a chur chun cinn sa tír. Freisin, níl aon chiall leis an bhfíoras nach bhfuil cead ag daoine saoirse a bheith acu, go háirithe sna meáin, nó ag saoránaigh i gcoitinne agus ba chóir freisin go gcuirfimis brú orthu toghcháin shaora a bheith acu sa tír.

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Mr President, I am defending the right of every person, whether Christian or Muslim, to exercise his religious duty. Another resolution? Another verbal condemnation for Algeria? If what we've heard is true, and I have no reason to believe it's not true, a verbal condemnation doesn't help at all, I think. Action should be taken.  As a Cypriot, I know what it means to be deprived of the right to exercise your religious duty. Most churches in Cyprus, in the occupied territories, have been converted by the Turks into stables and even lavatories. And I ask the Commission, in addition to verbal condemnation, in addition to the resolutions, will we take measures as the European Union if this is the case in Algeria?

name: Federica Mogherini
text: vice-présidente de la Commission / haute représentante de l’Union pour les affaires étrangères et la politique de sécurité. – Monsieur le Président, l’Algérie n’est pas seulement un pays voisin – elle l’est, bien sûr – mais elle est surtout un partenaire politique et économique, et un pays ami. Pour beaucoup de citoyens européens, l’Algérie représente aussi la famille. Nous ne parlons donc pas d’un pays parmi les autres, nous parlons d’un pays très proche de nous, un pays ami. Je pense que le premier sentiment que, nous tous en Europe, ressentons à l’égard du peuple algérien, c’est l’amitié et la proximité. Notre respect pour la souveraineté et l’autonomie de l’Algérie est total. Je pense qu’il est très important que ces débats le réaffirment de la plus forte et de la plus claire des manières. Il revient aux Algériens, à eux seuls, de décider du présent et de l’avenir de leur pays. C’est exactement pour cette raison que les Algériens doivent être libres de s’exprimer avec les garanties que leur assurent leur Constitution ainsi que les accords internationaux signés par l’Algérie. There are certain principles that Algeria has subscribed to, as some of you referred to: first and foremost in the Algerian Constitution but also with international agreements and with the association agreement that Algeria has with the European Union. These principles include all fundamental freedoms, including political freedoms, freedom of expression, the right to peaceful assembly, freedom of the press, and the freedoms guaranteed by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the cornerstone of our association agreements. So it is important that all the different actors in the current moment in Algeria can enjoy these rights. This is a message that not only comes from this debate today, but I think this is exactly the message we have consistently conveyed to our Algerian partners, interlocutors at all levels, constantly over this month. I believe that this will continue to be the message that the next Commission, the High Representative that is incoming, will continue to pass to our interlocutors in Algeria.  Algerians can build consensus around the future of the country, in line with people’s legitimate expectations and this can only happen peacefully and democratically in full respect of the principles that Algeria has subscribed to. I believe the European Union, as I said, will continue to engage with all Algerian players, as we have done so far, as neighbours, as partners and as friends and I am sure that this Parliament will accompany the work of the next Commission in this respect.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The debate is closed.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on five motions for resolutions on Cuba, namely the case of José Daniel Ferrer (2019/2929 (RSP)).

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: Author. – Mr President, "They have done to me everything: a thousand tortures and violence; I have been chained to my feet and hands; I have been put in the sun for a fortnight in a cell full of mosquitoes and cold in the early morning (risk of pneumonia). My life is in grave danger. If they don't move, I die." These words were written in a letter by José Daniel Ferrer, who managed to outwit his jailers to get her to his wife. May words also be heard today in the European Parliament calling for help from this man who has been suffering in the hands of castrism for more than a decade because of his human rights activism.  Mr. Ferrer's case is shocking. But like yours there are hundreds of more cases of political prisoners of conscience and thousands of pre-delictive prisoners well documented by the independent group The Cuban Prisoners Defenders. Torture, police violence against civil society, forced expatriations, political persecution, arbitrary arrests and imprisonment of activists, journalists and human rights defenders are crimes on the agenda committed in that Cuba by their authorities. We must demand the immediate release of José Daniel Ferrer and the many others who suffer human rights violations under the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation between the European Union and the Cuban Government, an agreement which, by the way, has had no positive impact on the Cuban civilian population. In addition to the Resolution, we will ask the new high representative to take into account the position of this Parliament in its dialogues with the Cuban authorities and to request the entry of our Parliament into Cuba.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: Author. – Mr President, today we are going to vote here on a resolution on Cuba, on José Daniel Ferrer, who is a political prisoner, one of the many political prisoners in one of the cruellest dictatorships in place today and which, however, is a dictatorship to which this Parliament and, above all, the European Union and the Commission are really dealing with in a way that it does not deserve. This was the case with the Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement which was signed against all those voices that said, that they remembered that concessions to a dictatorship that makes no concessions, that they always declare that they continue with what they have, that they will continue as a single party, that they will continue with the communist dictatorship and that no one expects changes in this regard are really a cooperation to reaffirm that dictatorship. That dictatorship that has launched into an expansionist adventure across the continent; which is currently in Venezuela, supporting one of the most monstrous dictatorships that has plunged The richest country in Latin America into hunger, despair and terror. A dictatorship that is destabilizing with Venezuela the democracies that exist in the region. In the face of that, I believe, I hope that there will be dignity in this Parliament to vote on that resolution for Ferrer's freedom and for Cuba's freedom.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: Author. – Mr President, the Socialist Group has shown in the negotiations – and now wants to reiterate – its concern about Ferrer's case. We demand your immediate release because we understand that your detention has been arbitrary and the conditions of your prison are not acceptable. No difference on that side. But we do part with the instrumentalisation of this unfortunate human rights case — which is the meaning of these issues of political importance — to question how, the Resolution does in most of its content, the current framework for European Union-Cuba relations.  The Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement was a vindication of the sterile twenty years of isolation with which we would re-align ourselves with the worst version of American policy on Cuba, which is sanctioning European companies that are acting there. The current framework, with its formalized dialogues on human rights, gives us more capacity for influence and pressure, and is more useful in general and for cases like this one in Ferrer. Critical engagement with Cuba is our model.

name: Manu PINEDA
text: Author. – Mr President, the right and the far right still do not accept that Mr Aznar's infamous common position is over. And they insist on making Mr. Trump's butlers. And for that they do not hesitate to raise fantasies like the one we just heard recently here. Today they bring us a text in which they instrumentalize the detention and judicial process, with all the guarantees, of a criminal accused of kidnapping and with a long history of sexist crimes, including beatings to his pregnant ex-wife of thirty-six weeks. In Cuba, the opposition acts with total normalcy. Where she is persecuted, repressed, arrested and sometimes murdered is in partner countries such as Colombia, Ecuador, Chile and, since the coup d'am, in Bolivia. You will not find images of the Cuban police suppressing opposition protesters, as we do see them every day in these exemplary democracies. Accusations about Cuba's alleged intervention in other Latin American countries are simply ridiculous. Cuba's only intervention in other countries, not just Latin America, is with troops of teachers and doctors. Not like the United States in Iraq, Syria and Libya, which seems to be of little concern to the authors of this text. Assume it. Cuba exists.  Follow the European Union on this. Respect and support an equal relationship with the Cuban people at once. Just be Democrats.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Author. – Mr. President, José Daniel Ferrer was arbitrarily detained and must be released now. But Mr Ferrer's case is just one of many examples of serious human rights violations that continue to occur in Cuba.  Mr Ferrer is one of the 127 political prisoners currently known; prisoners of a country that has signed an Agreement with the European Union which contains as its central element respect for human rights and the defence of democracy.  In 2017, this House approved the Agreement with Cuba on the condition that it contribute to improving the human rights and living conditions of all Cubans. Two years later, that condition is not being met. It is time for the European Union to speak out openly. Cuba is not complying with the Agreement. We therefore have no choice but to take action, without further delay, under the Agreement.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: for the PPE Group. – Mr President, High Representative of the European Union, the case of José Daniel Ferrero shows that communist Cuba will never deal with the still life of its past. Instead of opening up and having a dialogue with the opposition and with those who criticise it, it shows that it must close and torture again those who fight for freedom and democracy.  I had the opportunity to visit José Daniel Ferrera in Santiago de Cuba and had the opportunity to speak to him repeatedly. I think he is no terrorist, as some Cuban and pro-Cuban forces in this Parliament explain to us here. He is simply a person who wants to live in a democratic country, he is a person who loves his country, a person who would breathe for it, a person who was born there and wants to die there, and a person who respects all the things that we in the European Union respect. That is why I am calling, Commissioner, for you to use your relations with the Cuban regime to push for his immediate release.

name: Maria ARENA
text: José Daniel Ferrer is now in a deplorable state of health, without access to health care, after being arrested on 1 October. For more than a decade, he has been abused by the Cuban authorities for his peaceful political actions.  It is not the only one in this case. About 120 journalists, human rights defenders and peaceful dissidents are imprisoned in Cuba today. On 28 October, Armando Sosa Fortuny, the longest-serving prisoner, was killed in prison after 43 years in prison. According to international human rights standards, José Daniel Ferrer and all other prisoners have the right to know the reasons for their detention and to have access to a fair trial. I therefore call on the Cuban authorities to respect these international laws and to put an end to the constant attacks on those who exercise their freedom of expression. To do so, it is imperative that the Cuban government guarantee freedoms of the press, association and demonstration. We therefore call on them to respect the international standards set out in the charter as well as in the international declarations and instruments of which the country is a signatory, including the political dialogue agreement - to which you referred, High Representative - for cooperation with the European Union, which imposes respect for human rights.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, and my respect for you, Mrs Mogherini. In 2016 the European Union signed a treaty with Cuba that has as its essential and conditional component respect for human rights and democracy. This Parliament, in its Resolution of July 2017, conditioned it by adopting a suspension clause. Today Cuba has more than a hundred political prisoners and thousands of arbitrary arrests. José Daniel Ferrer is not a brutal anecdote. It is a category that shows that nothing has changed in Cuba, which remains the totalitarian regime of the "Castro dynasty". And I want to remember that the economy in Cuba is not the tourist palates but the military political complex of Gaesa, run by a former son-in-law of Raúl Castro. It's all family. The European Union cannot continue to close its eyes to reality. If we take business into ethics, let's be consistent. Let's remove items we don't want to fulfill. Let us recognize that our north is in that couplet of the poet Quevedo: "Powerful knight is a gift for money".

name: Guido REIL
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The leader of the Cuban democracy movement, José Daniel Ferrer, has been imprisoned – illegally – since 1 October, most likely being tortured. And what is the EU doing? We're watching. So, I think that's hypocritical. In similar cases in the recent past in Cambodia, Nicaragua and Iran, the EU has been much more active. And here we are watching.  Apparently, human rights are not so important in socialist dictatorships, where one can cash in. Because that's what It seems to me to be about: to make the cash. The Spanish economy in particular is now the third largest partner of this socialist dictatorship, Cuba, and the tourism companies, the hotel chains, make massive money. With hotels that remain closed to the Cubans – they are not even allowed in. But we must finally put an end to this.  Incidentally, the tourism industry is under the ministry of the Revolutionary Armed Forces, so that is significant. Human rights must apply throughout the world, including in socialist dictatorships.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Mr President, José Daniel Ferrer, who you are attempting in a resolution to heroise, is in charge of the so-called Patriotic Union of Cuba, the most active counter-revolutionary organisation in the country. He was arrested by Cuban authorities after a citizen complained that he and three other like-minded people beat him heavily, resulting in him needing hospitalization. Abuse, insufficient food, etc. are lies fabricated by the U.S. government and their embassy in Havana in order to present its dummies as victims. Ferrer, after all, is another character more recognizable to the staffs of the United States of America and the European Union than to his country and the Cuban people.  We denounce the European Union's industry of cutting, selective protection, so-called activists, the European Union's a-la-kart hypocritical concerns about human rights abuses, which are a familiar tool for more effective penetration of European monopolies into third countries, especially when these countries do not have governments of the preference of the European Union or its Member States.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would, of course, like to condemn the detention and procuring of Mr José Daniel Ferrer in prison in Cuba. I want to demand his release and, of course, a fair trial, because his accusations are clearly based on poor foundations. We should have a dialogue with the Cuban Government, I have nothing against that, but that does not mean that we will turn a blind eye to such cases of flagrant human rights violations in Cuba. It is not just this case, we still have more than 100 political prisoners in Cuban prisons. I think that we should strongly condemn this behaviour by the Cuban Government and ask it to make its actions much more vigorous in order to deal with its past.  The Czech Republic has always supported Cuban dissidents, and I will, of course, be no exception in this case, and I would ask the High Representative to unequivocally use her influence to release not only Mr Ferrero, but also other detained political prisoners in Cuba.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, Cuba is a shining example of what is possible against all the odds, with the most aggressive and violent power in the world for decades trying to overthrow your government, assassinate your leader and force your country into poverty and instability through sanctions; one of the first victims of the CIA regime-change formula. The US State Department wrote in 1960 of its failing campaign against Cuba that a programme of action should ‘make the greatest inroads in denying money and supplies to Cuba, to decrease monetary and real wages, to bring about hunger, desperation and overthrow of government’, and, sadly, they’re still at it. The truth of this: Ferrer was arrested on suspicion of the abduction and hospitalisation of a Cuban citizen. He is a right-wing agitator with a long history of violence, with close ties to the US. But this is really about attacking Cuba. it is about inflicting further economic sanctions and it is about trying to prevent the normalisation of relations with the US.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, this resolution is a deplorable exercise in the enumeration of false facts and grotesque considerations aimed at creating the context to justify the unqualified proposals for interference in Cuba's internal affairs and interference in the decisions of its people, in a clear violation of international law and the Charter of the United Nations, aimed at bringing down the Cuban revolution. It is another step towards jeopardising the progress that has been possible in normalising relations with the signing of the dialogue and cooperation agreement between Cuba and the European Union and its ratification by the Member States, even suggesting the possibility of suspending that agreement.  The resolution grossly omits the criminal blockade that has been taking action against Cuba for 60 years, its aggravation, its serious damage and consequences, while silencing the advances and economic, social and cultural rights that have been achieved by the Cuban revolution, as well as the recognized policy of international solidarity, particularly in the field of health, despite the blockade.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, I would like to strongly oppose the content and intent of this outrageous motion.
