Its intent is to undermine and isolate the Cuban Government and its people, at the behest of the United States, against the backdrop of increased hostility being meted out to that magnificent country and its incredibly resilient people. Its content is demonstrably false. José Daniel Ferrer is a convicted, violent thug awaiting trial for a violent crime. In the pay of the United States, he’s had all of his rights respected. To hear those who have championed US interventionism and supported unelected puppets in Bolivia and Venezuela call Cuban humanitarian aid, medical care and education to its Latin American neighbours ‘interventionism’ is simply outrageous. I salute the excellent work being done by the Cuban Government. I’m glad the Irish Government has cordial relations with Cuba and, despite this motion, they will continue.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, José Daniel Ferrer, the leader of the Patriotic Union of Cuba (UNPACU) was arrested on 1 October at his home in Santiago de Cuba and has been detained since. He has received visits – that have been limited – from his family, who have reported that his health is fragile. We have raised the case of José Daniel Ferrer, as well as other cases, with the Cuban authorities, both in Brussels and in Havana, most recently at the level of our Head of Delegation, who conducted an outreach on this issue to the Cuban Ministry of Foreign Affairs most recently on 6 November. The day after our intervention his family, including his three children, was able to visit him. Let me stress very clearly once again what we have declared many times: that we expect Cuba to respect every citizen’s fundamental freedoms and human dignity, including the right to a fair trial. In these years, we have never refrained from raising cases such as the one of Mr Ferrer, together with our Member States, in a coordinated manner and in a very proactive manner. Our engagement with Cuba on human rights is open and frank. We have no taboos, we address these issues at all levels, including at mine, every time that we see the need for doing that, and that is, unfortunately, quite often. We have chosen to engage with Cuba not because we see eye to eye on all issues, but precisely because we don’t. And let me say very clearly that I am proud that we have opened a new phase in our relations with Cuba during my mandate – let me stress this – with the full support of all of our Member States, no one excluded, no matter the political orientation of the government in place. I am proud that our political dialogue and cooperation agreement is in place, also because human rights are an essential part of it. And I’m proud of our critical engagement with the Cuban leadership, which gives us the opportunity to strengthen our cooperation but also to openly address our disagreements and to do something about them. The first formal dialogue we launched with Cuba under the new agreement was precisely on human rights, because respect for fundamental freedoms and for civil society is essential for us and is essential to us also because it can only be with the full respect of the space for civil society and human rights that economic development can be sustainable. Only through such critical engagement that we have opened with Cuba can we accompany the country in its modernisation. This is one of the goals of our agreements: accompanying the country as it reforms its political and economic model, building its economy on more solid foundations, and helping Cubans build a country where everyone enjoys the same freedoms and the same rights.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Haiti (2019/2928(RSP)). I would remind you once again that you can put your requests for spontaneous speeches and blue cards into the system both by the usual route and electronically.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Madam President, Haiti has long been a politically unstable country with a high level of corruption. A country that does not respect human rights, a country where journalists die, a country where personal freedoms are violated.  I think that the European Union should show its ability to negotiate dialogue between the opposition and between the ruling force. Because that's the only way we see a way to change that situation in any way. The European Union was the one that helped rebuild this beautiful country after the earthquake in Haiti. But we must also try to help restore the political and social climate in Haiti, which is one of the worst on the planet. I don't think the vast gap between rich and poor is the hardest thing we're going to find in this country. The hardest thing we find there is the instability and unpredictability of when you become a victim of crime or a victim of politically motivated violence. I think that needs to be changed urgently in this country.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Author. – Madam President, Haiti is probably one of the great forgotten of our public debate. An impoverished country, with completely sunk rates of human development and a very serious institutionality problem. I believe that what is happening in recent days forces us to condemn violence, to condemn repression. I have serious doubts, of course, that the current President Mose— who is accused of corruption by protesters, and there are clear indications that it may be true—is the right person to carry out what the country needs at the moment, which is a great national dialogue to restore some normalization.  In any case, I believe that the European Union should undoubtedly continue to support its instruments of cooperation with the country. In any case, it is clear that, in the face of their institutional difficulties, I understand that the support of development cooperation becomes extremely difficult. That is why this support for institutional standardisation – and this national dialogue – I believe must be an absolute priority right now. And with the five seconds left – as is the last time we will have the high representative here – I would simply like to use these last words to thank her for her work these last five years, full of activity, full of initiatives. I want to thank you very much for your efforts over this time.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I, too, will start by thanking the High Representative for these five years of working with Parliament, including with me personally – in the context of Eastern policy, the Eastern Partnership. And I think this cooperation was effective.  Ladies and about! Haiti is one of the poorest countries in the world, a country hit cyclically by dramatic natural disasters. The European Union and the whole world are trying to support the country humanely. The fact is that this not entirely controlled, monitored humanitarian aid often does not go to those who are most in need. So we have to monitor very closely what's going on with this money. I must say that I am from the Polish, our soldiers were stationed in Haiti in the early nineteenth century. This is a particular reason to be interested in and help this country.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: Author. – Madam President, Madam High Representative, I would like to begin by thanking you for your excellent mandate. The political and social situation in Haiti is unsustainable. Street protests are a justified sign of the revolt against an administration without transparency and against unacceptable practices that lead to impoverishment, exploitation of the most unprotected, insecurity and serious deterioration of living conditions of the vast majority of the population. The European Union's commitment to cooperate with the people of Haiti to find a path of stability, development and democracy, while respecting the rule of law, must therefore be underlined and applied on a permanent basis. The European Parliament resolution we are debating here today reinforces support for this line of action, while condemning the violent repression of the free expression of Haitians by the haitian authorities. It is essential that international relations increase their humanitarian aid effort in a situation of deep crisis, but no support will have the necessary impact if the Haitian authorities do not immediately guarantee, as required, the restoration of the rule of law and freedom of expression while respecting the human rights and just demands of the people.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Madam President, Haiti is the poorest country in America. He is the victim of austere policies of international organizations, a colossal debt imposed by these entities and a ruling class that fills his pockets with money for social projects. As a result, the population is condemned to misery. Profiting from the misfortune of millions of people is once again the recipe for casino capitalism. Thousands of Haitians have been on the streets for a year and a half demanding the resignation of the president and the end of neoliberal policies. Dozens have been killed by police, who are also accused of ties to armed groups responsible for massacres and cases of sexual violence. And all this in the face of the silence of the international community. We condemn repression against the Haitian people and complicit international silence. We also call for an end to austericidal and neoliberal policies, as well as debt forgiveness so that the Haitian people can have a future with dignity. Mrs Mogherini, I hope we don't have to miss her with whatever comes in the next legislature.

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: Author. – Madam President! Haiti. One of the poorest countries already plagued by economic underdevelopment and inequality. Terrible plight of the population, violence, discrimination, stigma. Even the systems of modern forms of child slavery, and on top of that, successive natural disasters.  Haiti has been heating up in the past year in increasing chaos and a major humanitarian catastrophe. Barricades of protesters, power outages, lack of operational government, blocked access to aid, escalation of violence.  All this prevents people there from fundamental human rights, access to food, drinking water, emergency medical assistance, access to young people to school.  I am not asking and calling, but I am asking all sides in Haiti to stop the violence and causing additional suffering to the people. I condemn the violent killing of protesters, the restriction of reporting, the threats, the murder of three journalists. The EU must react, it must come to the rescue concretely.

name: Seán KELLY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I’m sorry to say but Haiti could probably be described as one of the most immoral states in the world. Immoral morality abounds. Just look at the list: widespread corruption, an unlawful police force, no government, no parliament come next year, harassment and aggression against journalists, murders, rape, discrimination against women, LGBTI people classed under Haitian laws as the same as those guilty of child pornography and incest and a reason to deny citizenship, violence against elderly people and – perhaps worst of all – children unable to go to school. I think if there’s one thing we could at least try it is to put pressure on the Haitian government is to try and give young people the chance to go to school, because there is no progress without school.

name: Neena GILL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, High Representative, as we’ve already heard, Haiti is a country almost on the brink of collapse. Economic struggles have led to violent protests and shootings with dozens of deaths, at least 20 people killed at the hands of the security forces, and many more have been severely injured. The violence has led to children missing school and people struggling to access sufficient food, drinking water, medicine and fuel. The health sector is facing shortages in electricity, fuel, supplies and an inability to reach people in need of treatment. The EU needs to play a real effort to find a meaningful inclusive resolution to the current solution, especially addressing concerns around corruption. Haiti is an ACP partner. Ensuring its sustainable development is vital if we are serious in the effort to tackle the climate change, corruption and chaos there. High Representative, what leverage are you using, given that we have hundreds of millions of euros through EDF to push for a political solution to alleviate the suffering of the people of Haiti? And finally, I would once again like to wish you all the best for your future endeavours, and thank you very much for everything you have done.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, permanent humanitarian crisis in Haiti. A country that, when it has not yet recovered from a major natural catastrophe, already has another health crisis and a political crisis. A country that is indeed one of the poorest on the planet, which is dominated by poverty, inequality, insecurity and, unfortunately, corruption. There are still 38,000 people from the 2010 earthquake un relocated. And since September there has been a violent crisis — a situation of very worrying violence — precisely because of society's protests against the government and lack of supply.  That is why I believe that, in the face of more than forty deceased people, according to the United Nations, including three murdered journalists who were covering precisely these revolts, we must work to call for an end to violence, to call for a political exit that goes through transparent and fair elections and, of course, to ask for and support humanitarian aid in a country where 40% of the population depends on international food aid. Very good luck, Commissioner.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, hell exists and is in Haiti. Corruption, violence and poverty are now normal for the Haitian people, a country where human rights are trampled underfoot every day before our very eyes. We cannot stand by and watch without intervening. There is still slavery in Haiti and thousands of children are sold every year as servants to the wealthiest families. In Haiti, women who are raped do not find justice and cannot even have abortions, gender equality does not even exist before the law. In Haiti, if you go down to protest too often, you don't come home anymore. According to data from the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, at least 42 people were killed and more than 80 injured during the protests in September and October. The list is long, but I think that is enough, as we have said today, to ask a simple question: why are we allowing all this? Thank you, Mr President, and I greet Mr Mogherini for his career.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, just very briefly, I want to support the resolution on Haiti. In the last parliamentary term, we dealt several times with the very difficult social and political situation in this extremely poor country. Tensions have been building up there recently, with people protesting because of the very difficult social situation in which they find themselves. There are a lot of people really below the poverty line, it's been said here, there's child slavery going on, it's really big problems. It will be up to the new Commission, the new High Representative, to try to have some kind of dialogue with this country, which would at least lead to those demonstrating and expressing their rights being able to express those rights without being sanctioned. Then we need to have a debate with the government in Haiti on how to improve the social situation of the poorest.  We support this country economically, but we should do some reflection that it, too, perceives that human rights should be at least of some value.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, I congratulate Mrs Mogherini. I find that in his mandate there have been so many situations, it is like you should be a firefighter, go to put out a situation on one side and there is an immediate violation of human rights elsewhere. I hope that the next High Representative will continue this work and develop it. But on the other hand, I think it is time for this Parliament, which we, the Euro-Members elected by the European people, should find an international, transparent way for there to be control of these human rights and a verification and condemnation of those who make flagrant violations in this area. In my view, the 21st century is about human rights, and I hope that together we will find this solution. Once again good luck and thank you for what you have done so far.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the protests in Haiti calling for the resignation of President Jovenel Moïse have been going on since July. The haitian people's revolt began following the cancellation of government fuel subsidies and more thorough fiscal control, conditions set by the International Monetary Fund to restart the country. The effects of these measures were felt immediately and were devastating. In addition to the removal of fuel subsidies, there are also the difficulties arising from the embargo imposed by the United States on Venezuela. Yet this disaster was not difficult to imagine. Haiti is the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere and in this context subsidy cuts have not been complemented by compensatory measures to protect the most vulnerable sections of the population. President Moïse does not appear to be planning to leave office for the time being, nor to abandon the presidency or the non-liberal policies he is adopting. He still has the support of the United States and the Core Group, the group of so-called friends of Haiti, including the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, the time has come to change our policy and promote a change of system to ensure fairness and justice for our Haitian friends.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I will start with a picture that has literally gone around the world – a Haitian senator shooting into the air in front of people. These are pictures of contrast in Haiti. The contrast between total poverty and the world of the rich.  For me, it is important to condemn such behaviour, of course the riots and violent protests are mainly against the corrupt government and President Jovenel Moïs. They are continuing precisely as a result of rising food and fuel prices. They escalated radically this fall. Haiti is also the case in the country where the journalist was killed, his murder is falling in the index of the protection of journalists and the freedom of their work. Dialogue with the opposition needs to be established, we should clearly say this to the Haitian Government, investigate corruption and focus on fundamental human rights. People have nothing to eat and drink, and this should be the main concern of the Haitian government. I would like to wish the High Representative all the good for her future work and thank her for her service here in the European Union.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President. For two months, Haiti has been engulfed in protests which were triggered by fuel shortages and quickly turned violent, morphing into a campaign against the President. According to UN figures, at least 42 people have been killed and dozens injured during these anti-government protests. Violence is fuelling further insecurity in an already fragile state racked with poverty, inequality and corruption. More than one in three Haitians need urgent assistance to meet their daily food requirements, meaning that nearly 3.7 million people are going hungry. Yet aid organisations are struggling to provide relief to those most in need. The EU must work with the Haitian authorities to provide urgent humanitarian assistance. Another deplorable act of violence that’s occurred during this unrest is violence against women in state prisons, where women are detained in the same cells as men and subject to rape. Here in the European Parliament we’re marking the 16 Days of Action to end gender-based violence. So let’s not forget these vulnerable women in one of the poorest countries in the world.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – The poorest country in the Americas is now paralysed by a crisis that is political as well as social and economic. Large segments of the population are protesting against the way the country is currently governed and particularly against corruption and mismanagement cases that have involved high figures in the institutions. Young activists are at the forefront of the protest, but farmers and shopkeepers have also joined, and after years of economic crisis, the country is now facing a constitutional crisis too, with no government and no parliament. The protests started, as some of you have mentioned, over fuel shortages over the summer, and these are now paralysing the country. Businesses, hospitals, schools, government institutions are often closed, transport throughout the country has become very complicated, including for humanitarian aid, and the country is basically at a standstill. Political stances are getting more radical, the humanitarian crisis is worsening, and gang—related violence is also on the rise. We have been and constantly are following very closely the current crisis, coordinating with the countries and institutions from the core group. We also have urged the authorities to conduct effective and thorough investigations into crimes. The authorities must guarantee the right to demonstrate freely and peacefully, and violence must be avoided under all circumstances. I expressed this position on behalf of the 28 Member States earlier this month. We also called on all actors to engage in a national dialogue to identify consensual solutions to the current crisis in its political, economic and humanitarian dimensions. Let me also recall that the European Union is also coordinating with other donors to provide urgent relief inside the country, because the humanitarian situation is dramatic. Yet the current situation is clearly unsustainable. It’s not only a matter of humanitarian aid, it’s a political process that can create the conditions for the international community to support the country’s long—term development. Signora Presidente, mi consenta, per concludere, innanzitutto di utilizzare la mia lingua, cosa che ho fatto raramente in questo emiciclo, per ringraziare di un'ottima collaborazione che abbiamo avuto lungo questi cinque anni, all'inizio di questo mandato parlamentare, in questi ultimi mesi, e i colleghi parlamentari europei che sono stati in questi banchi nei quattro anni e mezzo precedenti. Ho sempre dato estrema importanza al ruolo della diplomazia parlamentare. Credo che il ruolo del Parlamento europeo sia fondamentale non soltanto per la democrazia europea ma anche per il nostro lavoro per la pace, la sicurezza e una politica estera cooperativa nel mondo, soprattutto in questo mondo di oggi. Vorrei sinceramente ringraziare i membri del Parlamento, tutti, il Presidente, i Vicepresidenti, tutti i gruppi politici e in particolare le due commissioni con le quali ho avuto il piacere di lavorare più strettamente, la commissione per gli affari esteri e la commissione per lo sviluppo, che hanno sempre sostenuto in modo fondamentale il mio lavoro in questi anni. Grazie mille. (Applausi)

name: Nicola BEER
text: High Representative Mogherini! On behalf of the whole House, I would like to thank you for your cooperation with Parliament, but also with the relevant committees, but also, of course, for your personal commitment to the European Union and the idea of cooperation in multilateral institutions. Thank you very much for this work and especially for the passion you have shown. (Applause) The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate. (The sitting was adjourned at 11.12 a.m. until the vote)

name: Klára DOBREV
text: I would like to welcome you, the representatives of 500 million European citizens, to today’s plenary session. Let me start with an announcement.  Pursuant to Article 53 of the Regulation of the European Union 2018/1725 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 23 October 2018, the Conference of Presidents, at its meeting of 28 November 2019, following the deliberation of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, approved the joint appointment by Parliament and the Council of Mr Wojciech Wiewiórowski, as European Data Protection Supervisor. The President will sign the appointment decision together with the President-in-Office of the Council.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the European Union cannot be silent to what is going on in the current days in Malta around the investigations into the assassination of the journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, and certainly not this Parliament, who’s press room has her name. This week, two ministers and the Chief of Staff of Prime Minister Muscat resigned over the recent shocking developments. All these people appeared in the investigations of Daphne Caruana Galizia before she was killed. Nevertheless, Prime Minister Muscat has protected them all this time and defended them again and again, while attacking those who wanted to expose them. The situation in Malta has consequences for the entire European project. I think this Parliament needs to point out, now more than ever, to the Maltese authorities that the assassination of journalists with clear political links must have clear political consequences. I have always seen this Parliament raising its voice very high to claim the respect of rule of law and of the freedom of the press to several governments in Europe. Today, it’s time to do the same in the case of Malta. Let’s raise our voice together. (Applause)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, the S&D Group has always been, is and will be next to the rule of law. Always. Without choosing who we put ourselves next to when it suits us or stops agreeing. In any case, I want to say one thing clear. The rule of law works when suspects are arrested and legal proceedings are opened. That's what happened last week in Malta. A suspect has been arrested and a judicial process has been opened. This Parliament must respect judicial processes and not interfere with them, and in any case I would like to clarify that this group is always on the side of truth and justice. Others should know and understand that you can't choose when you're on the side... (Protests) Mind. Well, I'm not going to shut up. I'm not going to shut up. There are people who might be disturbed that I'm clarifying one thing here. Truth and justice are not chosen. You always have to be on the same side. And we own our words and we must be consistent. The People's Party here today has made one thing clear. I hope that for the five years you will always be on the side of the rule of law, wherever it is, in whatever country, the governing person rules. (Applause)

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: – Madam President, I would only like to make clear that it is crucial to the situation in Malta that this Parliament sends an urgent mission in order to fact-find what’s happening. I thank Mr Weber for his words. It’s overdue that the prize in Malta which has been decided by the last Parliament is finally installed for the freedom of journalism. And this Parliament has never taken side in politics in Malta but searched for the truth and justice for Daphne Caruana Galizia. This is what this is about and nothing else.  (Applause)

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, I can be very short and I am speaking as the Chair of the Rule of Law Monitoring Group, which met this morning. We are planning a visit to Malta, but we will be very clear: there will not be any political interference or taking sides. We are not going to interfere in any police investigation or proceedings, but we will make sure that the European Parliament keeps the pressure up so that justice is done and the truth will come to light. And in that spirit, we will decide when and how to travel to Malta. (Applause)

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Madam President, I just want to make a point of the internal regulation, Article 132, paragraph 2. On Monday evening, we had a debate on the climate and environmental emergency, with the word emergency in English. In some amendments, it is proposed that the title of the resolution be changed so that the term urgency is used. However, as the title of our debate on Monday evening included the word emergency, we consider that these amendments must be declared inadmissible.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The title of the debate can be different from the title of the resolution, so we can go on.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, pursuant to Rule 195, I would like to move for a point of order. There is an amendment that we have tabled in conjunction with some other political groups but, with a sense of responsibility towards this House, we will be abstaining on that amendment. It is Amendment 11. It speaks about a climate emergency and we’re doing this because, after a meeting yesterday, we understood that there are groups that are willing to threaten the whole COP resolution because of that amendment, and we are responsible. We have a resolution now that speaks about climate emergency. We will not endanger a resolution on COP25. We want the European Parliament to go strongly united, together with the PPE and other political groups, with a strong COP25 resolution. (Applause)

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I am formally requesting the withdrawal of my support and the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists for the resolution on the Madrid Climate Conference (COP25) in order to speed up the achievement of the 2050 climate neutrality target and to increase the 2030 emission reduction target to 55%. In addition, the parliamentary majority wants to give a red light not only to energy from coal, but also to gas and nuclear energy. Such objectives will be detrimental to the European economy and have not been agreed with the Member States. This is required in accordance with the Treaties.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Madam President, I do not want to add to the length of the meeting but would like to make a proposal in the interest of our visitors. We have a lot of groups of visitors who, when they attend the debates, understand everything without problems, no matter where they are located. However, at the time of the vote, only the visitors in front of you understand what is going on and see the tables. So I would like to see a proposal to install two paintings in front of you so that other visitors also understand what is going on.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Thank you very much for your comment. We will consider it.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Antony HOOK
text: – (inaudible) ...voted for this new Commission, and the fact that the Commission is elected and remains accountable to this Parliament, is vital. We voted on the candidates put forward by the elected governments of every Member State, and now we have elected them, this new Commission must get to work. Because beyond this hall, people are waiting to be helped: people facing the danger of climate change, people facing the uncertainty of a changing economy, people feeling insufficient power in their own lives. The Commission’s job is to give everyone good grounds to look forward to the next five years with hope instead of fear. If the UK makes the mistake of Brexit, giving up our voice in Europe, the decisions made here will still shape the UK’s future. As a British MEP, I voted in this election for the Commission because I expect Brexit will be stopped, and this will be the Commission of all European citizens.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, unfortunately, the European Union is in a climate hysteria that is far removed from some rational reasoning, and unfortunately this climate hysteria has unfortunately been printed on the agenda of the new European Commission. I cannot agree with the objectives set by the European Commission in the fight against climate change, I consider them unrealistic, unfeasible and even harmful to a number of European economies. I think that this will have an impact on the energy mix in individual countries, on their industrial structure, on employment, and that this will also be reflected in citizens' wallets. This is the main reason why I could not support this European Commission with my vote.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I did not support the new European Commission with my vote yesterday, because of its programme, which the new Commission plans to promote and which is a drowning programme that will significantly worsen the competitiveness of the Countries of the European Union. It is easy to set targets that satisfy different activists, but it is not realistic to meet or approach such targets. The result of this green utopia will be only the devastation of European industry, the rise in energy prices and the increase in citizens' discontent. Industrial enterprises that are unable to respond to the changes will be closed and their market share will be taken by Chinese, Indian or American firms without environmental limits and control. And this green revolution will have to be paid for by our citizens with their taxes. There will be no impact on the world climate, because the European Union is the only one taking these steps.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, I congratulate the new Commission on their election yesterday, but I would not pretend that the process over these past few months has been perfect, because it hasn’t. But importantly, it has built in the chance for Members of this House to change their minds. We voted back in July on the appointment of President-elect von der Leyen. We then had several weeks to examine the detail of the Commission’s proposed work programme, to scrutinise, to challenge nominees to the Commission. We then voted yesterday in what you could describe as a confirmatory vote on whether we want to confirm our original decision of July or not. And I would suggest that the idea of a confirmatory vote, of giving people the chance to perhaps change their minds from decisions made previously, might be an important principle that could be extended to bigger questions elsewhere.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, I abstained on this motion on grounds that very soon this will be none of Britain’s business. If it were still the case that we were staying in the European Union, I’d have had a lot to say about the individual merits and demerits of some of these candidates, and I’d certainly have had a lot to say about the appointments process, the concentration of executive and legislative power in the hands of 28 officials who are immune to the ballot box and invulnerable to public opinion. But happily, this is going to cease to be our problem, so I instead wish you every success and look forward, instead of being a difficult Member, to being good neighbours. ¡Suerte! Viel Glück! Bon courage!

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Madam President, I voted against the investiture of the von der Leyen Commission, because I believe it will aggravate the situation in France in three key areas. First of all, it is in favour of an organisation of immigration in Europe while I expect something else: a resolute policy of combating migration submersion. Secondly, it wants to strengthen European integration, while the French people have put in the lead, in the European elections, a party - the National Rally - which advocates respect for national sovereignty. Finally, it wants to continue the crazy globalized free trade policy that has ruined our agriculture. The promotion of Phil Hogan is a sad symbol of this. For these three reasons, I will strongly oppose the von der Leyen Commission throughout my term of office.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, I voted against the new Commission, because to say it was elected is a misnomer. It is not accountable to each and every voter in any of the European countries. It undermines national sovereignty and is an assault on each and every voter. But many here snidely dismiss national sovereignty as reactionary, nationalist, xenophobic and far right. What a slander as a way of de-legitimising voters. I am an internationalist and on the left. I believe real European solidarity is to respect the voters of each and every European country, and I urge my fellow Democrats who are here as MEPs not to pretend that this place is a place of democracy but to stay true to their voters and to respect their votes – and they can have nothing to do with recalling or holding anyone here accountable. Don’t let’s con them.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I have supported the Commission with my vote. I did it for some very good reasons. Firstly, in my opinion, the European Parliament has fulfilled its role by removing the weak pieces – several Commissioners – from the Commission. Those who did not have financial issues, conflicts of interest resolved or had weaknesses in their history. All this was important to me, because this makes the Commission credible for me. The European Commission is also credible in its programme for other reasons, responding to the urgent challenges of the times, not pretending that climate change is happening and wanting to respond adequately, adequately, rationally. Digitalisation – a fundamental, long-term issue – and, of course, social justice are all the reasons that led me to support the Commission. I ask: what would have been the other way if the Commission had not been approved? Chaos? Another six months of delay? We would lose a whole year of that from the entire parliamentary term. I don't think we could afford this, so I supported the Commission.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: – Thank you President, I supported the Commission's appointment because I welcome its green social direction. We all need a green direction to survive, and socially we need to live with dignity. I also welcome the digitisation of scientific innovation and the maintenance of our old areas such as agriculture and regional reinforcement, the levelling of support for farmers, which is needed in various regions, including the Baltic and Lithuania. This requires European leadership, European leadership is needed by our people, and our neighbours in the south, Africa and the Eastern Partnership also need it. Only by working together will the European Parliament and the Commission be able to achieve results that will meet the expectations of the people of Europe and enable us to feel that we have served the people of Europe fairly.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Madam President, I voted against the new Commission because I believe the appointments reinforce my view that the European Union is institutionally racist. Ten percent of Europe’s population comes from a racial or ethnic minority, but there’s never been a black Commissioner here. There’s no one of any colour in any senior management role; no black person employed by the EU has ever spoken to this Parliament. This is not Europe united in diversity; it’s an apartheid. Here, black Europeans are not segregated by the bus they travel on, they are segregated by time. During the day the EU is for white people. At night, we let the black people in to wash the floors and clean the toilets. Ms von der Leyen could insist her Commissioners hired people of colour, as she has done for women. She could instruct the Commission to change its employment practices and hire and recruit more black people. The President boasted in her speech yesterday about changing the face of the Commission, but only, I believe, as long as those faces are white. The EU is institutionally racist and I won’t vote for those white slave masters.

name: Judith BUNTING
text: – Madam President, as a British MEP I am proud to be part of a sovereign nation that works alongside our partners in Europe to tackle climate change. Throughout Europe, governments and local councils have been declaring a climate emergency, but today this Parliament became the first parliament in the world to declare a climate emergency across a continent.  We must take urgent action to reverse the damage done to our planet before it is too late. Time is running out. It is imperative that we all reduce our carbon footprint in every aspect of our lives. From the food on our plate to the technology we use, from the exploitation of our oceans and the imports from trade outside our block, we will work together to reduce our footprint, not just in Europe but also across the globe. Change starts here!

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, I have just criticised the European Commission for its climate policy, now I have to commend it for the plans it has with the European budget in the next financial period, particularly as regards the transfer of funds from that eating, from direct sponsorship of the common agricultural policy or cohesion policy to promoting innovation, science, research, technology. Unfortunately, this has not yet manifested itself in this press, everything remains the same there, and I think it would be good to send a signal in this way to the new European Commission that we are counting on the commitments made yesterday by its President in her opening remarks. So I could not support this press in this vote because it is not in line with what I would like the next European budget to look like.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I, too, did not support the 2020 budget yesterday. Unfortunately, expenditure continues to grow, and it is also being incurred in areas that have nothing to do with the competences of the European Union. They do not strengthen the competitiveness of the European Union or its Member States. This is a waste of taxpayers' money that cannot be justified. Subsidies, which the European Union considers essential, are rather harmful to the cohesion instrument in many areas. I am talking in particular about subsidies to business entities, which should also be restricted. Those are the reasons why I didn't support the budget.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I was happy to support this resolution. In the last parliamentary term, we have debated many times about the situation in Bolivia, where President Morales is taking this country, and we have expressed concern about the situation in that country. At a time when there were great doubts about the regularity of the elections in which President Morales was to be re-elected, the fact that this dictator eventually fled the country, and that at the moment both chambers of the Bolivian Parliament are preparing new, free presidential elections, should satisfy us and fill us with joy. On the other hand, everything must be done to ensure that these elections are actually conducted properly and that the situation in this very impoverished country continues to improve.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, I supported this motion, and it was, I think, an important debate that we had in the last number of weeks on this particular issue. The fact of the matter is we can no longer deny the science. The science is there – it’s very evident. There is global warming. It has been identified because of the amount of carbon emissions, fossil-fuel burning and how we just exploit our planet, which are the real reasons why we have this emergency. And we have to take, from time to time, the advice of younger generations. There are thousands of people in Ireland on every Friday – young students protesting, highlighting the deficiencies of effort on behalf of politicians and political leaders across the globe. It is time for us now to accept that we have an emergency and accepting that to respond with an emergency in terms of developing policies that will immediately impact on saving the planet, saving the environment, saving the biodiversity and saving our oceans. It has gone beyond whether or not it is an urgency or an emergency. It is very evident. It is what it is, and we must act now with policies that will address it.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, I don’t believe the resolution that we passed today to declare a climate emergency would have happened had it not been for the campaigning and the pressure of those thousands of young people in all parts of the world – those young people walking out of their schools and colleges as they did in Leicester a few weeks ago, when I was pleased to join them. But they’ve done that not to demand of us that we pass resolutions or adopt encouraging words. They’ve done that to demand real, meaningful, decisive action, and that’s what we must now deliver. That’s what the new Commission must deliver, that’s what our national governments must deliver, and it’s what we as a Parliament must ensure is delivered. Because if one thing is clear from those young people, from Greta Thunberg when she spoke to this Parliament a few months ago, words are not enough. They want action and they are right to demand that action of us.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, I voted against the climate and environmental emergency motion because I’m really concerned at the hyped-up anti-science scaremongering that’s terrifying young people, telling them that billions will die, that there’ll be a collapse of civilisation, a lot of the rhetoric coming out of Extinction Rebellion and echoed in the debate over the last few days. I think that the fact that we voted against an amendment today that said that we should be committed to bringing environmental subject back to rational discussion, and we rejected it, admits that actually we’re having an irrational discussion. This becomes advocacy and propaganda, rather than science. There’s no scientific evidence from the IPCC or anyone else about the extinction of humanity, and we should be very careful about claiming that anthropological climate changes cause floods and droughts, which we have been doing quite casually during the last few days. In fact, the IPCC says that such issues are probably caused by socio-economic conditions, and we forget socio-economic conditions too much and demand, in fact, as this Parliament has done, decarbonisation, which will lead to eco-austerity, massive price hikes in energy, and ordinary working people paying the cost for scaremongering and... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: – Madam President, I’d just like to reiterate what my colleague said. I also rejected the COP24 resolution. I may not be an Economics Professor, but I do profess to understand economics. They also call it the dismal science, but when it comes to the climate emergency, I would describe the apocalyptic forecasts as nothing but science fiction. The adoption of these policies today, and the aim of carbon neutrality by 2050, is nothing short of reckless and the most extreme example of economic illiteracy I’ve ever seen. The fact that amendments were rejected demanding a full impact assessment shows rank indifference to the cost and practicality of aggressive climate policies.  One thing I can say for certain is that the impact of net zero makes the consequence of any form of Brexit look puny by comparison. Dieter Helm, Professor of Energy and Economics at Oxford University, was right when he said: ‘We should be honest that it is a huge industrial undertaking, and it will have significant cost. These are enormous industrial activities, there is nothing in history that looks like this outside of wartime.’ In my own country, our own Chancellor has put that cost at over one trillion pounds, or almost 2% of GDP per annum. It is an insane policy.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: Madam President, today, 28 November 2019, the European Parliament declares a state of climate and environmental emergency. This is a symbolic and historic moment, and I am proud, by my vote, to have contributed to it. Europe, which, since the industrial revolution, has contributed greatly to the climate catastrophe, has risen to a duty of responsibility to the peoples of the world, to the species and to the young people of the world who are asking us to act now. We must therefore act now to ensure that life remains possible on Earth, for the human species and for all species that have entered an unprecedented wave of extinction. There is no longer an urgent need to wait, it is urgent to act.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to explain why I finally abstained on this resolution. I believe that the European Parliament is calling for very ambitious targets, and I think it is the Duty of the European Union to support the Member States in reducing carbon dioxide and greenhouse gases. The objectives that have been proposed are ambitious. Even the 50% now in the proposal by 2030 is ambitious. An increase to fifty-five percent without knowing the effects was not possible, in my view. That's why I got held up in the end. I am glad that, in this resolution, we finally deleted in the vote a provision prohibiting the further use of atomic energy in energy production, which I think would be completely unmanageable for many states. So I got held up.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, I did not support the resolution on the climate and environmental state of emergency because, although climate change does, the measures proposed therein affect the sovereignty and interests of the Member States in a way that violates their interest. I strongly disagree with attempts to increase the agreed level of ambition by 2030 and the European nationally determined contribution.  Moreover, such a change so soon after the adoption of legislation would in an inadmissible compromise legal certainty and lead to a complete lack of predictability for the industry and the economy as a whole. Account must also be taken of the impact of the UK's departure on the European Union, which will lead to a real increase in the industrial objectives of the remaining Member States.  I'm from Bulgaria. This is a country that is an external border of the European Union. Imposing such a large reduction would put our country at risk of shifting production across borders to third countries outside the European Union and shift carbon emissions to countries where such measures are not in place.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I support this resolution and welcome Parliament’s ambitious agenda on climate change for the next five years. Reaching the ambitious objectives set out at COP21 in Paris, where I was honoured to represent Parliament, is of the utmost importance if we are to honour the wishes of EU citizens and avoid further irreversible damage to our planet. While the EU continues to be a world leader on climate action, this has to be an international effort, and the need for greater collective ambition must be recognised. It is vital that the climate change debate is inclusive and leaves nobody behind, and for this reason I take issue with the provision to phase out fossil fuel subsidies by 2020. While we need to move away from fossil subsidies, ending them by 2020 next year would deny citizens access to much-needed fuel allowances. This is a gradual process, and ending fuel allowances next year would have a severe impact on low-income families and pensioners who cannot otherwise afford heating for their homes. As Commission President von der Leyen said: ‘The transition to renewable energy sources must be fair and inclusive, as it is ambitious’.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, I strongly voted against the Istanbul Convention with very clear reasons. This document is anything but a document aimed at protecting women's rights and protecting women from violence. This is a document that represents the emanation of a propaganda that is inadmissible to me, namely gender propaganda, which invades schools, into universities, destroying communities, destroying traditional families in eastern European countries. It is no coincidence that a number of Eastern European Member States are against it. Not because they are against the fight against violence against women, but because they are against this propaganda that aims to replace our traditional values, something that we cannot and will not agree to.  It is unacceptable and unacceptable to formulate and define the social role of gender. Gender is biology and there is no choice. It cannot be and will never be a social thinker or some kind of choice. It's pure and simple biology. For this reason, this document is unacceptable. We in Bulgaria have not ratified it and we will not.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I could not support the resolution, which once again calls on all the remaining States of the European Union to ratify the Istanbul Convention without delay. In particular, it shall designate Bulgaria, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Slovakia and the United Kingdom to do so without delay. I believe that this is a mystification, that it is an attempt to create the impression that the adoption of the Istanbul Convention is the solution. The solution is really the fight against violence against women, and I know this from examples from the Czech Republic, which has adopted a law against domestic violence, which has adopted measures within the criminal code, in the framework of education and other measures to combat violence against women effectively. She did not need to ratify the Istanbul Convention to do so. And I insist that it is the competence of the Member States, and the European Parliament should not constantly call on the Member States to do something they do not want to do.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour, recognising that violence against women and girls mostly goes unreported. Last year alone, almost 40 000 women and girls in my home region were known survivors of domestic abuse, and over 8 000 experienced sexual violence. These shocking numbers have no place in our society, and I’m appalled that the Istanbul Convention has not yet been ratified by the United Kingdom. We can’t claim to be a leading economy, a world power, if we’re systematically failing some of our most vulnerable and most valuable citizens. Enough is enough. Our society must be a safe place for our daughters, our sisters, our mothers. No more holding our keys when we walk home at night, no more ‘what did she wear, what did she drink?’ No more shutting us down when we speak up. Europe must now criminalise violence against women and girls.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, in 2017, 1 998 women intentionally killed; 87 983 women raped; 123 871 subject to sexual assaults across 22 EU Member States. Those numbers are shocking, they are shameful, they are frightening, and they are why we have to pass the strongest possible laws at every level against violence against women. And in that year, 2017, in my own country, 250 intentional homicides against women. It’s outrageous that my government in the UK has not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention, but it’s also outrageous that as a direct result of funding cuts and austerity under this government, rape crisis centres and refuges and other vital services are struggling to keep their doors open. Austerity is putting the safety of women at risk.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Mr Kelly, before I give you the floor, I would like to remind all of us that the deadline for submitting requests for oral explanations of vote is the start of the session. After the session starts in the future there will be no possibility, but this time the floor is yours.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, tá brón orm as ucht an bhotúin sin. I voted in favour and fully support all progress towards EU accession to the Istanbul Convention, which is the most comprehensive international treaty in fighting violence against women. Tragically, a third of all women and girls experience physical or sexual violence in their lifetime. Furthermore, many victims are afraid to come forward and report such incidents. This is unacceptable and we must take the necessary steps to enact meaningful change for women across Europe. This much is clear.  The Convention, which was ratified by Ireland earlier this year, is the first in Europe to set legally binding standards specifically to prevent gender-based violence. The EU’s accession to the Convention would reaffirm our commitment to achieving gender balance. Agus mar fhocal scoir, iarraim ar na Ballstáit nár chuir Coinbhinsiún Iostanbúl ina ndlíthe féin é a dhéanamh go práinneach agus gan mhoill.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: – Thank you, honourable President, honourable colleagues, indeed Russia's actions against Lithuanian judges, investigators and prosecutors, an unprecedented event that attempts to interfere in the law enforcement of another country. Our values, the rule of law, are important not only for Lithuania, but also for the European Union as a whole. Therefore, our decision to respond to Russia's actions is very important. I witnessed 13 January 1991, when tanks and soldiers of the Soviet Union killed unarmed civilians. Some of them I had as a doctor to treat. Today we have done the right thing by expressing the European Parliament's decision that no one can influence independent judges. Thank you to all those who voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Madam President, I voted against this resolution. An independent judiciary is impossible if there is a state monopoly on historic truth. In Lithuania, any deviation from the formula that only armed forces of the USSR were responsible for the deaths of 14 demonstrators on 13 January 1991 is a subject for criminal responsibility, and the journalist and politician of Lithuania, Algirdas Paleckis, who declared during a radio discussion that ‘it appears that in January 1991 our own people were shooting at their natives’, was sentenced to a fine, despite the fact that he found several witnesses and ballistic assessments showing that there were secret snipers on the roofs who were shooting civilians on 13 January 1991. Recently Algirdas was even arrested and accused of spying for Russia. Lithuania should abolish political restrictions on discussing and investigating the events of 13 January 1991.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this resolution. As a former Minister of Justice of the Czech Republic, I believe that we need to be up for independent courts in any Member State. Unlike the previously said, I do not think that this is a question of interpreting the interpretation of what happened in Lithuania in 1991. It is a question of the rule of law. Independent judges and investigators and prosecutors have made some decisions, they have a legal opinion and someone discriminates against them for it. Moreover, it is a foreign country, it is Russia, that is the question of the dispute. I am neither willing nor able to interpret 1991 in Lithuania, but it bothers me, as a lawyer and a man who has defended the rule of law all his life, that a judge is sanctioned for his legal opinion. This is unacceptable, we must reject this and we must stand up for the Lithuanian judges, because lithuanian justice is a European judiciary, and it therefore applies to the entire European Union and therefore to us if we defend the rule of law.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour. The ancient Airbus—Boeing dispute over aerospace subsidies is now spilling over to hurt other businesses. Never mind who’s right or wrong, we now have an adverse ruling from the WTO that we have to deal with, and four EU Member States have been singled out. All have reacted strongly, except the UK. The French, German and Spanish governments, and the European Commission, have said that they will respond in kind with their own tariffs. Meanwhile, our International Trade Secretary expressed her disappointment, providing absolutely no relief to Scotch whisky producers now facing 25% tariffs. The Tories have been hypnotised by the US. They continue to expect a golden era of transatlantic trade relations and free trade post-Brexit against all of the evidence. Trump’s ‘America First’ trade agenda is a direct threat to British jobs and our prosperity, but the Tories are blinded to it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, I voted in favour of this resolution because it concerns a problem of huge importance, namely customs duties. The European Union has always tried to open up its markets and conclude trade agreements with third countries as well. The new duties imposed by the United States loosen the so-called Euro-Atlantic Partnership.  The food industry is one of the most important in the member states and is dependent, of course, on the decisions taken by Washington that will increase volatility in domestic markets and our producers. It is not normal and it is not moral because of the commercial dispute between two competing companies, namely Airbus and Boeing, to affect an entire sector in this industry. Neither consumers nor small and medium-sized businesses should be hostage to an economic conflict in the aviation sector.  The Commission must do everything possible to address this situation and avoid further budget cuts in the sector by launching immediate negotiations with the United States of America in order to find a solution.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I would like to explain why I voted in favour of this resolution. Given that the World Trade Organisation has identified some errors in the European Union's action to support Airbus, we have no choice but to accept $7.5 billion in sanctions. However, it is inconceivable that European farmers should pay for this misconduct. Exports of European agricultural products to the US reached more than twenty-two and a half billion euros in 2018. This is making the US one of the most important destinations in exports, and we do not want to go to war with the US. We want to have a good relationship with them. That is also why the European Union and the US need to agree. We cannot wait for a decision on Boeing and wage a trade war with the US, but we must act and support those parts of the agricultural sector that, say, would be sanctioned by the US. In this, the European Union must be united and in solidarity.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour, as for many Brexiteers the WTO has become the land of milk and honey, with Donald Trump in the role of Moses, leading the British people to the promised land of global free trade. But what their story doesn’t say is that Trump has been busy destroying the WTO for the past three years, and he’s about to succeed. Because of the US, the WTO will effectively cease to function in exactly two weeks’ time. Another example of the many lies used to justify Brexit to the British people. The truth is that from the perspective of international trade, the EU is by far the best option for Britain. Only the EU can resolve this situation and get the WTO up and running again. We’ve seen determined and concrete efforts in Brussels to keep UK—exporting businesses afloat. What we get from the Tories is myth and rhetoric.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of the motion for the resolution for the ongoing negotiations of the ACP-EU Partnership Agreement, and I did it in the context of the fact that we are now in a globalised world. I think that dialogue is critically important, and I believe that some form of parliamentary assembly that would allow people to discuss in an open forum the challenges facing people in Europe, in Africa, in the Pacific and the Caribbean, to deal with these challenges in an open way. Human rights, climate change, the rule of law, supporting democracy: they’re all key issues that we should all be involved in. So it should not be Europe lecturing to anybody, it should be Europe listening, embracing, and others having an opportunity to advocate how we should also address some of the challenges and decisions we make that impact negatively on those countries. So let us establish this joint parliamentary assembly, promote democracy and human rights, champion climate change and ensure that the rule of law is upheld.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item on the agenda is oral question to the Commission on 0800 customer service numbers, tabled by Andreas Schwab, Christian Ehler, Pilar del Castillo Vera, Angelika Niebler, Róża Thun und Hohenstein, Edina Tóth, on behalf of the PPE Group (O-000037/2019 – B9 0059/2019) (2019/2937(RSP)).

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The subject we have chosen this afternoon as the subject of our oral question to the Commission is: what about the electronic internal market for telephone services? We have already discussed this on several occasions, together with many other colleagues in the Committee on the Internal Market. The subject to be discussed this afternoon is a very local issue here in the Strasbourg area. A German citizen mentioned to me that his mother-in-law was in hospital in Strasbourg and that he did not manage to call her during her stay there, because the hospital there kindly offers a 0800 number – a free service number – for french citizens, which, however, cannot be reached from other European countries, which is only a few kilometres away in this situation. I believe, Commissioner Gabriel, that we need to address the question in a very specific way: can the European internal telecommunications market look like this, that we have abolished cross-border roaming charges, but that citizens in the neighbouring country can no longer call their in-laws in the neighbouring country uncomplicatedly because of a 0800 number there? In my view, this is indisputable, because the advantage of the 0800 number is precisely that the citizen can call uncomplicatedly – namely free of charge – and if it is impossible across borders, we have done the European internal market a disservice. That is why I would like to know from the Commission – but together with all the colleagues who are here this afternoon – what we can do to remedy this maladministration, to ensure that not only the bill for cross-border telephone calls remains favourable, but that cross-border accessibility is reliably resolved, even in the case of service numbers. That is why it is important for the European Commission to give us a clear answer here. This maladministration must be rectified.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the Members of the European Parliament for drawing our attention to this important issue. The European Commission believes it is important to guarantee access to the number 0 800. We will look at this issue in detail, first of all because - as you have just rightly said, Mr Schwab - this issue is essential for the completion of the Digital Single Market. Companies typically use 0 800 numbers to provide better customer service. It is often a decision that aims to provide assistance in an easier and more effective way. In the case of a free 0 800 number, the cost of the call is carried over to the named party, such as a company with a customer helpline.  In order to avoid any risk of fraud and to protect the caller from the high costs associated with calls from abroad, especially for small NGOs such as cancer helpline, national and European legislation does not prohibit callers from refusing calls made from abroad. So far, we have not received many complaints, but I do not trust that. Whether there are many or few, that is not the question, we are talking about something essential and concrete. Therefore, I would like to see what other means we have. I draw your attention to the directive that establishes the new European code for electronic communications. You remember, we adopted it last year. This new code has introduced various measures aimed precisely at combating cross-border distortions and eliminating their effects. Therefore, we know that the code will contribute to the completion of the single market. It is currently expected to come into force in December 2020, and the Commission is cooperating closely with Member States to help them implement it. Of course, the European Parliament is always welcome in this process. We will have the same objective: to ensure that the new measures established by the code are operational after December next year, and we will follow up carefully. Therefore, we will continue to follow this issue. Completion of the Digital Single Market is a first-rate goal and we have already made good progress. We now have a set of policies, investment measures and regulatory initiatives that have given European companies important tools for digital competitiveness and, at the same time, strengthened user rights. As you know, we have abolished roaming charges across the European Union. Recently, we have introduced reduced rates for international calls in Member States. These two measures have made a significant contribution to ensuring that European consumers feel concerned about a genuine digital single market policy. At this stage, I can assure you that the Commission will continue to monitor the situation of access to the number 0 800 closely, and it is on this basis that further action will be taken, in line with, I repeat, the evolution of the situation. Today's debate is also a contribution for which we thank you.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Thank you very much for this ambitious declaration, which we take here very seriously, because the helplines are indeed very popular in many sectors: the banking sector, mobile networks and many others. They are crucial, including in terms of traffic information, railway information, consumer information and much more. But when I'm abroad, we won't use the consumer helpline yet, because in the handsee – and I've experienced it myself – instead of information about my consumer rights or other advice, I hear, "At the moment, the number is unreachable." And this will also happen to anyone who wants to contact the 24-hour free hotline for children, for young people, for parents, for educators. Instead of getting professional help from experienced psychologists, educators, experienced lawyers, there is silence in the handsee.  According to data available in my country, Poland, from the National Health Fund, the hotline supports almost 40,000 calls per month. I do not see any obstacles as to why the hotline service in Poland could not be available to people from outside my country who are currently in Poland and urgently need information about the availability of hospitals, e.g. for themselves or for a loved one, and have a number that does not start at +48.  Next, of course, we need to reflect on the issue of the universal operation of such hotlines in a foreign language once they have been internationalised, because I completely agree with the Commissioner that, as we all know, law, technical or administrative solutions must make life easier for us, they must make life easier for the citizens of the European Union, not create barriers and obstacles to communication. Finally, Andreas Schwab rightly recalled: we won with roaming or with the prices of international calls. That is why I am absolutely determined to work on extending the functioning of the national hotline to international calls, and I am convinced that we will achieve this in good cooperation with the new European Commission (which I wish you every success).

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I am happy to be here to work again for the telecommunication operators and then the citizens’ needs, and I see the internal market of the telecommunication as an essential part. During the last mandate, Europe has taken important steps towards the regulation of the international calls lately, which will come to power only at the end of next year and will also lower the price there. And then we know the success story of the roaming. I’m happy to be the rapporteur and see that results have been causing more happiness than these problems. But then of course, informing the consumers is the most important. I also read the petition made by the German gentleman who was on holiday in France and wanted to call the hospital and thought it was a free number because it started 0800. So then first of all the consumer needs to know if it’s not free when they make a phone call. But I also want to look at the existing law. There are two parts. There are businesses that want to offer services across the EU. It is, of course, then in their interest also to pay the price instead of the customer. But then we do have this possibility also to use this 0800 numbers for the public services such as hospitals. I don’t very easily see the potential there to serve the citizens, because if they’re negotiating the whole euro price, instead of the one country where the hospital is located, I might think that they don’t want to serve these free phone calls for everyone, because the hospital in Finland cannot serve the language of the Greek grandparent or the Polish friend. So it’s more complicated than the easy answer, which would be to make it free for everywhere. In Finland there is a proposal now that nationwide service numbers may not be any price they want. There is now the proposal that service numbers must be included in the unlimited data prices and not have external prices as they are nowadays, not in the price regulation, because even many public services use them. So I’m curious to ask if the Commission sees that possibility, that model, that those national service numbers could be the way forward then also to help the model that they are not excessive. And I’m always in favour of unlimited packages, whether it’s data or telephones. It really gives the purposes for the users to have access to digital services in a more broad way and then having that one as the main goal to make the low price for the telephone users – it serves the people best. But I’m curious also to see this cross-border situation. But we have to understand when it’s close and cross-border, it automatically talks from Italy to Lapland and makes more variety for the question to be understood from the pricing side.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Undoubtedly, a great deal has been achieved in recent years in order to create a single telecommunications market in the European Union, which is a very important part of the common market. An EU emergency number 112 has been created. The European Electronic Communications Code, which the Commissioner has referred to and which will fully enter into force by the end of next year, has been adopted. EU rules on roaming have been introduced – first roaming phone calls, then data roaming, although it must be said here that telecommunications companies are still exploiting every loophole in the law to charge consumers additional fees. Unfortunately, this is still the case in my country, Poland. Nevertheless, progress is enormous.  Indeed, access to 0800 numbers is perhaps one of the last barriers that separates us from the creation of a full single telecommunications market within the European Union. This is so important that many of these numbers are numbers operated by business, as my finnish colleague said, and here, of course, we cannot pour a child with a bath – we must remember that with the lifting of these restrictions, business will bear higher costs, costs will increase for callers abroad. However, let us also remember that 0800 numbers are used in the public service.  Mr Schwab, the author of this question, shows an extremely important example, namely access to medical information.  In Poland, many Poles who work in other countries on a daily basis today, after the abolition of roaming fallout, have mobile area codes from other countries of the European Union. They, as Mrs Thun said, wanting to receive information in public hospitals today and by calling 0800, cannot get that information.  I therefore thank Commissioner Gabriel very much for the very ambitious promises she has made here, and I encourage the European Commission to be active in this matter.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Dear Madam President, Honourable Commissioner, allow me to first congratulate you on your re-election and wish you another controversial five-year term as successful as the previous one. Here I start with your achievements in dropping roaming and fighting for no roaming to the Western Balkans (this is foreseen on this topic, this was successful). But listening to colleagues who insist on introducing this number and making it free, I wonder how much this will cost and who will pay this bill. Whenever such proposals are made, there must be some sense, because we do not live in socialism, dear colleagues, nor communism, but we live in a union that is founded on the idea of a single free market. There is no doubt that people should be able to search for information about their loved ones, but this should be translated through some reasonable algorithm.  Therefore, Commissioner, you have my support and I hope you will offer a sensible and feasible solution to this problem. It will not be either fast or cheap – it is clear to everyone, but it must be reasonable and feasible.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, firstly, thanks to Mr Schwab for bringing this topic to our attention, and also to the Commissioner for dealing with it adequately. I’ve been a member of this House now for 10 years, and each part-session, someone or other will always stand up and say: ‘We must complete the single market. We must complete the digital single market.’ Now, we’ve made some good progress – obviously, roaming and geo-blocking, complementarity – we did a lot of work on that. And as she said, there’s no point in completing something unless the customers are aware of it. That’s the second point. But I would like to say to Mariya Gabriel, because she has a great record: wouldn’t it be great if she could be the person who could come in to this Parliament over the next five years and say: ‘Actually we have completed the single market, we have completed the digital single market.’ And I think the way to do it is something like what we’ve been doing. Where are the obstacles? Where are the loopholes? Pick them off, deal with them, get them out of the way one by one and do that over the next five years and we’ll make fantastic progress. So Mariya, over to you.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, first of all, I would really like to thank the European Parliament for raising this important issue of access to the number 0 800. Thank you also for your support for the measures proposed and implemented so far for the completion of the Digital Single Market. I would now like to respond a little more in detail, because the questions from Ms Miapetra Kumpula-Natri and Mr Kelly were very specific. The first thing... Why is the cost of calls to 0800 from abroad difficult to establish? It's very clear because actually we are talking about obstacles, but it's a unilateral economic decision and in the case of calls from abroad the cost of the call may be difficult to establish as the called party cannot keep the fees such as transit and call termination fees under control, contrary to costs on a national level and may be exposed to fraudulent practices. This is why under national and European legislation it is not prohibited to refuse calls from abroad.  Now where we are, and what we have achieved in order to give you some European answers. First, our reference is the new Code of Electronic Communications. We said it very clearly. It will become effective in the Member States as of 21 December 2020 next year. But, the Code has introduced measures to avoid cross—border distortions and will further contribute to the completion of the single market. An example of such a measure is the introduction of single maximum Union-wide voice termination rates by a delegated act which the Commission will adopt by the end of next year. Thanks to such a measure, one of the cost elements will decrease over time and the risk of increased overall cost, transit and interconnection costs for the called party, the company contracting the free phone number, the bank or travel or agency, are therefore likely to be mitigated over time. On our side, at the European Commission, we will closely monitor the development to see if further action is needed. Madam President, once again, I would like to thank the Members of Parliament for this debate, which is useful for us and for our follow-up work. As I just said, we will continue to monitor the market and developments in this area to determine whether further action is needed in the future. The message is this: we have made several progress, we will see what effects they will produce. Already, thanks to this debate, we will also be following trends and developments more closely in order to be able to act in time. Because technologies are evolving extremely fast, it is important for us too not to fall behind. Thank you very much, Madam President, and thank you again to the Members of Parliament.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Edina TÓTH
text: Writing. – The introduction of European emergency number 112 was an important step towards the single telecommunications market and the fullering of the rights of European citizens in distress. This harmonisation, however, is incomplete, since the 800 toll-free customer service number does not cover cross-border calls. It is time for family members of hospital patients to make quick and easy phone calls and request information on the health of a relative in another Member State, which is why the 800 customer service number should be made uniform throughout the European Union.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: I declare adjourned the session of the European Parliament.
